B000001EIA|4.0|After all the years, who'd have thought that KISS would become a nostalgia act? On \\"MTV Unplugged,\\" KISS not only tugs the heart strings, but proves they had the chops as a band all along. They have two of the expected songs here (\\"Beth\\" and \\"RnR All Night\\") but for the most part they re-tool some of the more obscure numbers. I have always considered \\"A World Without Heroes\\" to be Gene's best song, and on \\"Unplugged,\\" it's a stand out.<br />There's also genuine joy in the air. \\"Coming Home\\" opens things here, making this \\"Hotter Than Hell\\" track take on a whole new definition. Stanley is very at home in this setting, and his voice is a much better instrument than many people have given him credit for. Listen to his emoting on \\"I Still Want You,\\" which becomes a ballad with power instead of a mere power ballad!<br />Even by the end of the show, when they bring out the \\"members of the family,\\" the level of excitement is as high as a bunch of grown men revisiting their glory days can get. Ace is obviously thrilled to get another stab at \\"2000 Man,\\" and Peter just wails on \\"Nothing To Lose.\\" It's enough to make you forgive them the way too obvious closing of \\"Rock And Roll All Night.\\" But as far as KISS' live albums go, this is the one I'd choose to listen to after the first \\"Alive!\\" It's really that good.

There are excellent huapangos, trios  and just pure musical genius  composed by award winner Elliot Goldenthal that you will enjoy. You will love this festive, at times melancholic, at other times dreamy variety of Mexican folkloric music. The booklet is also very nice with pictures from the movie and complete bilingual lyrics to all the music. If you haven't seen the movie check it out; whether you have seen the movie or not this disc will create cinematic hues for your listening experience. A highly recommended disc for fans of  a variety of Mexican musical styles.Mexican musical styles.

B000006TRV|4.0|This album is really not as good as you may hear, it certainly doesn't hold a candle to WISH YOU WERE HERE (which is my personal favorite) or ANIMALS. There are some very impressive tracks from THE WALL, but not enough to be called Pink Floyd's greatest album. There are too many sketchy points in this album, it's not as strong or as consistent as some of their earlier works. I find myself skipping through most of the songs because either they're too bland and insipid, or they're exactly like the song I just heard. I'm not saying THE WALL is horrible or even bad, I'm just saying that this is not the first Pink Floyd album you should go for. B000084T18|5.0|When I originally heard \\"How To Rob\\" from the \\"In Too Deep\\" soundtrack, I liked the song and the clever wordplay involved, but I wondered if 50 Cent had enough to carry a whole album.  Rappers like Jay Z, Ghostface Killah, Sticky Fingaz from Onyx and others weren't too pleased with what 50 had to say and they came out with their own things to say about the song.   Just as 50 was about to record his 1st single from \\"Power Of The Dollar\\", \\"Thug Love\\" w/Destiny's Child, 50 was shot multiple times.    After he recovered, 50 called his label and they acted as if 50 had never even existed.   To reestablish himelf, 50 hit the mixtape circuit and would appear on various mixtapes freestyling or with songs that were supposed to appear on \\"Power Of The Dollar\\".   In early 2002, Full Clip Records released \\"Guess Who's Back\\" which included underground songs and freestyles that included 50, G Unit, Nas, Nature, The Bravehearts and Bun B of UGK on different tracks.  Shortly after that, 50 Cent & G Unit released several mixed Cds and the buzz definitely had been recreated.  Eminem heard \\"Guess Who's Back\\" after he completed \\"The Eminem Show\\" and that was the beginning of 50 Cent being signed to Eminem's Shady Records.   50 Cent's popular mix tape track, \\"Wanksta\\" appeared on Eminem's \\"8 Mile\\" soundtrack, as well as,  \\"Places To Go\\" and \\"Love Me\\" which was  a collaboration with Eminem, 50 Cent and Obie Trice.   These songs and the mixed CDs were enough to keep 50 out in the streets until his highly anticipated CD, \\"Get Rich Or Die Trying\\", was released.   When \\"In Da Club\\" was released to radio and started appearing on MTV and BET, 50's CD was definitely going to be in demand.  Dr. Dre's club banger had everyone sayig \\"Go, go, go, go, go..\\".  The song would propel \\"Get Rich Or Die Trying\\" with over 800,000 units sold in the first four days of its release.  The CD gets off a nice start with \\"What's Up Gangsta\\".  Fans of 50's street releases will definitely like this track.  Next up is \\"Patiently Waiting\\" as Eminem and 50 collaborate on the Eminem produced track.   50 and Eminem rip the track to shreds.  On \\"Many Men (Wish Death)\\", 50 speaks about how after being shot multiple times, how he reflects on things and how your enemies and people that are jealous of you are always plotting behind your back.   This is one of \\"Get Rich Or Die Trying's\\" best tracks.   Dr. Dre shows up again to produce the passion filled \\"Heat\\".   50 is back in street mode once again and has an anthem for anyone that wants to come at him and his G Unit crew.  \\"If I Can't\\" is more of a radio friendly Dre song but you will forget the commercial appeal of the song once you hear 50 rhyming to the track.   \\"Back Down\\" has 50 speaking on his long term beef with Ja Rule.   This is the CD's best track, in my opinion, as 50 says, \\"You're a pop tart, sweetheart, you're soft in the middle...\\".   Since then there have been several back and forth disses with the latest being \\"Hail Mary 2003\\" with Eminem, 50 Cent & Busta Rhymes.  The 2nd single, \\"21 Questions\\" with Nate Dogg is an ode for the ladies that will definitely continue to keep \\"Get Rich Or Die Trying\\" on the charts for awhile.  \\"Don't Push Me\\" w/Lloyd Banks of G Unit and Eminem, has 50 Cent rapping a little too much like 2 Pac for some people.   I like the song as the rappers flow lovely to the Eminem's beat.  \\"Poor Lil Rich\\" is a Sha Money XL track that plans keep 50 in heavy club rotation along with the aforementioned \\"In Da Club\\" and \\"P.I.M.P\\".    The only song that you will have to fast forward, in my opinion, is \\"Blood Hound\\" with Young Buck as it sounds like DMX is barking throughout the whole song. \\"Get Rich Or Die Trying\\" also includes \\"Wanksta\\", \\"U Not Like Me\\", and \\"Life's On The Line\\" as bonus tracks, but loyal 50 fans have heard these tracks already.   50 recently released a DVD, \\"The New Breed\\" that included a bonus CD with 3 tracks:  \\"True Loyalty\\" with G Unit, \\"8 Mile Road\\" (G Unit Remix)with G Unit, and the Dr. Dre produced \\"In Da Hood\\" with Brooklyn.  To anyone who doesn't know G Unit is 50 Cent, Lloyd Banks, Tony Yayo, Young Buck, Bang 'Em Smurf and a cast of other characters.  G Unit recently signed with Interscope Records, so a G Unit CD and a Lloyd Banks solo CD should be out by the end of the year and expect a new 50 Cent CD by February 2004.   For 50 Cent the sky is the limit.   If you judge \\"Get Rich Or Die Trying\\" by just \\"In Da Club\\" and \\"21 Questions\\" then you will be saddenly mistakened.   This CD has more than club friendly songs on it.  Fans of 50's street anthems will enjoy this CD as well.  I wonder how Columbia feels now that 50 Cent has sold more than 4 million records in 10 weeks?   I would advise you to get \\"Get Rich Or Die Trying\\" and \\"Guess Who's Back\\" to start your 50 library.   FREE YAYO!!!!<br />James' Top 5<br />1) Back Down<BR>2) Many Men (Wish Death)<BR>3) P.I.M.P<BR>4) What Up Gangsta<BR>5) 21 Questions w/Nate Dogg

B00008S2VG|5.0|Ok, let's face it. This CD will get a LOT of bad reviews (namely from ignorant people who automatically assume that this album is anti-American and anti-Bush). But I will give this CD a fair, and good review, because it's well... a good CD! This album is somewhat dark and dreary when it comes to the meanings behind the songs... There's not one happy song on here, but they are ALL so good! I sense a mid-life crisis thing going on here, but that just gives Madge more inspiration...<br />1. American Life (10/10) - The first single. You either love it or you hate it. We've all heard it by now, of course. I personally think it's a genius song, and that Madonna made a right choice by making this the first single. She should NOT have pulled the video though! The original video is so great. (I PERSONALLY LOVE MADONNA'S RAP! =D)<br />2. Hollywood (8/10) - The second single. It's upbeat, acoustic, with hints of electronic usage. The lyrics are very depressing, reflecting upon the dark side of Hollywood people choose to ignore. Very summery, and a great choice for the second single. The only bad part of the song is near the end, Madonna repeats this one line, but each time she sounds more like a man...and it's kinda creepy.<br />3. I'm So Stupid (9/10) - This self-degrading song is pure genius. It's acoustic with a lot of techno influence, and it's got a dark feeling to it. The intro overshadows the rest of the song however, with it's soft singing and light guitar stringing. However, there's something in the beginning of the song that might hurt your ears... you'll see what I mean... and no, your CD player isn't broken.<br />4. Love Profusion (9/10) - Another folky guitar song. This one is really sweet though, and actually incredibly catchy. It's a little sadder than the previous tracks, and has somewhat of more prominant techno influence. The best part is near the middle where she sings \\"I've got you under my skin\\" over and over. Great meaning about loving everyone for who they are.<br />5. Nobody Knows Me (10/10) - Er... ok... This song is a very bizarre one, but it's actually one of the best on here. It's an upbeat, electronic, club song. I love dancing to this, and I've only had it for a day. It sounds a lot more like jumbled sound effects than an actual instrumentation. It comes out being genius though. I hope this is a single!<br />6. Nothing Fails (10/10) - WHOA! This song is AMAZING! It starts off a simple guitar love song... but wow... this is undescribable... it slowly escalates into a giant ballad with a choir and violens. This is amazing... it's slated to be the third single, and I sure hope it is! I love the line \\"I'm not religious, but I feel so good...\\" Spine chilling!<br />7. Intervention (10/10) - All of the best tracks were shoved near the end! Very unique tracklisting. This song is so simple, yet so incredibly sweet. It's probably one of the darkest on here (Tied with Mother And Father and Easy Ride). It's so beautiful... It's so true too. It's about how love can save you from anything, if you let it...<br />8. X-Static Process (8/10) - The most folky song on here... funny, because with this name it seems like it'd be a club song. I really don't like it that much, but the lryics are pretty. It's about religion, and struggling with it. The best lyric on here, period, is \\"I always wished I could find someone as beautiful as you, but in the process I forgot that I was special too...\\"<br />9. Mother And Father (10/10) - WOW! 80's influenced electro/funk! Even if it sounds A LOT like Kylie Minogue's \\"Fever\\" (The song, not the album), it's so GENIUS! It's really depressing if you listen to the lyrics and think about them... it's about losing your mother. Madonna raps here too, but it's somewhat more sparatic than on American Life.<br />10. Die Another Day (10/10) - I liked this song from the moment I heard it, and even now I still like! I'll agree, it wasn't meant to be a Bond song, but it's still a great dance song. We've all heard this, so no need to go into detail. This IS the full version however (You know, the one in the video).<br />11. Easy Ride (10/10) - MY FAVORITE TRACK PERIOD! The DARKEST and DEEPEST song on here! It is so depressing! I love it, it's so beautiful, and... wow I just can't describe how amazing this song is. It's orchestrated, and... WOW I JUST CAN'T DESCRIBE THIS! You SO need to hear this song! There's definately some Frozen influence going on here too. BEST TRACK.<br />In conclusion, I highly suggest you buy this. It IS NOT ANTI-AMERICAN! Don't believe all that in magazines, TV, radio, etc... it's all lies. It's really amazing, and incredibly soulful and deep. There's no enhanced section though =( that was a lie. lol.

B00008S2VG|5.0|I have concluded that the people who write reviews for newspapers must be in an orchestrated conspiracy to trash Madonna at every opportunity they can. Obviously, there is no newspaper reviewer who has actually listened to American Life more than once, if at all. Their transparent and intentionally vicious reviews show just how out of touch they are with the industry they review. To these individuals, Madonna cannot do anything right.<br />Anyway, I will admit, when I first heard the single American Life, I was a bit numb; I was not quite sure what to think of it. However, while it has in fact grown on me, it is not my favorite on the album. Now that I have had an entire day to listen to this CD, I have decided that it is one of my all time favorite Madonna compilations. For me, it ranks up there with Ray of Light. <br />Unlike Music, this CD is very listenable and full of potential singles. My favorite tracks are Easy Ride, Love Profusion and Mother  & Father. This CD harkens back to her first album, Madonna. There is a definite techno/disco thing going on here. Her very first single Everybody comes to mind on more than one track. <br />I have read comparisons made between American Life and Music; I completely disagree. While there is a plethora of guitar, the composure of the songs is more mature and complex. Particularly in the songs Nothing Fails and Easy Ride, the combination of a techno beat, guitar and string instruments is quite soothing. I absolutely love it; I just wish there were a couple of more songs.  <br />If you a die-hard Madonna fan, this is a must for your collection. If you are an occasional Madonna fan, I think you will like this album, especially if you liked Ray of Light. If you are not really a Madonna fan but get into the rhythms and beats of techno, you should find something you like on this CD.
0316666343|2.0|I started off reading this book with much enthusiasm and interest. The premise was captivating and Alice Sebold is a good writer. I could really sense the pain of the family and Sebold does a good job of providing hints of what it must feel like to be dead while watching the world go on below you. I even liked her basic concept of heaven (it jived with some basic concepts found in orthodox Christianity, meaning it had some elements of truth).<br />However, the book soon descended into a typical, baby-boomer lamentation about the plight of repressed suburbanite women (and their justifiable adultery), the superiority of smart and artistic people, and the absolute normality and goodness of sexual encounters, no matter what age or what circumstance.<br />Every author has an agenda, but not only did I disagree with Sebold's post-modern feminist outlook on life, I was annoyed by the ham-handed way in which she injected it into the narrative once she ran out of good story ideas.<br />Great premise, poor execution.

They just don't, and that's all there is to it. 7/10<br />NOTHING FAILS-Another nice piece of guitar-playing. More great lyrics. &quot;It was not a chance meeting Feel my heart beating You're the one You could take all this Take it away I'd still have it all Cuz I've climbed the tree of life And that is why No longer scared if I fall If I get lost in space I can return to this place Cuz you're the one Nothing fails No more fears You washed away my tears&quot;. 8/10<br />INTERVENTION-Good lyrics and a very good vocal performance from the middle onward. Still, the song drags on a little bit. If it moved along a little faster and had been worked on a little more, it's point would have been made quite a bit more clearly. 8/10<br />X-STATIC PROCESS-Excellent excellent excellent! She reflects on her connection with Jesus. &quot;Don't really know if I should give a damn When you're around I don't know who I am I always wished that I could find someone as beautiful as you But in the process I forgot that I was special too&quot; Very moving, very saddening. Makes you think. 10/10<br />MOTHER AND FATHER-Extremely excellent again! She reflects on her relationships with her mother and father and her childhood. &quot;There was a time I was happy in my life, believed I'd live forever There was time I prayed to Jesus Christ There was a time I had a mother it was nice...Nobody else could ever take the place of you&quot;. She also apologizes to her father. He tried, really he did. She just didn't understand where he was coming from and that he didn't know to react. Just beautiful. She comes clean. This is Madonna uncensored. 10/10<br />DIE ANOTHER DAY-The Bond theme we all know and love. Just like her Top 40 hit SPOTLIGHT, I believe this song is as much a personal anthem for her as it is the movie's. If you didn't buy the Soundtrack to the album but bought the CD maxi only like myself, then you won't find anything new. It pretty much just drags on a little slower towards the end of the track. Still, a great addition to the disc thought it hardly fits with the other 10 cuts. Anyone notice how it seems to borrow some of the music from PAPA DON'T PREACH? 9/10<br />EASY RIDE-She talks about how she wants a good life but she doesn't want an easy ride. She wants to feel &quot;blood and sweat on her fingertips&quot;. She wants to find her place, breathe the air and feel the sun on her childrens' face. Nice guitar-playing, if a slightly less than inspired vocal performance. Good song all in all-it makes its point. 7/10<br />All in all, for a Madonna fan, this album is great. It holds to the formula she's been following the past five years while still, you feel she's clearly going into a new direction, and that new directions are to come in the future.<br />Madonna, you've done it again.e music from PAPA DON'T PREACH? 9/10<br />EASY RIDE-She talks about how she wants a good life but she doesn't want an easy ride. B00008OLYN|4.0|Ever since their debut album came out in 1994, the Swedish death-metal band Opeth have always written acoustic passages to create a more dynamic mood in their songs, and usually to a great effect. Six albums and almost ten years later, they've finally released a softer album that even non-metalheads can crank up the headphones to. And when I mean softer, I mean no lightning-fast solos, no guttural screaming vocals, and no pounding double-bass drums. This is a heavy metal band, but this is far from a heavy metal album.<br />Unlike their previous six albums, the majority of the eight tracks are actually songs written with accessability in mind.  No twelve minute suites are found here, but the opening track \\"Windowpane\\" certainly leans in that direction.  Most songs are written in the standard verse-chorus-solo formula, and Opeth have proven they can do that as well with high marks all around. The themes discussed in lyrics are similar to previous albums: lament, regret, melancholy. There are only two reasons I don't give this album the fifth star. Although the songs are solidly written, most of them are a bit too similar for my tastes. Also, 45 minutes is not quite long enough to qualify as album length these days.<br />I got this album because I am a diehard fan of whatever the four members put out. However, I really think that this CD has the crossover potential to break into the popular American market.  I personally suggest checking out \\"To Rid The Disease\\" and \\"Closure\\" to find out if this album is for you.

0385493622|5.0|Here is a nice simple book for those of you who like to explore things avoiding technicalities.<br />If you are not a math or science major, you would ask me: why should I read this book? I would answer: because math appeals to a large number of people, and, you got to admit it, in this period of time people must know something about it. This theorem, in addition, had puzzled great mathematicians (even geniuses) for more than three and a half century.<br />The book starts with some exploration of Greek mathematics, being the base of modern mathematics. Here we must see something about the Pythagorean Theorem, because it inspired the Fermat's Last theorem.<br />He moves then to speak about Fermat, the French mathematician. He mentions that Fermat did not in fact write a proof for his theorem due to the limitation of the margins of his copy of Diaphintine's &quot;Arithmetica,&quot; and this caused the whole mathematical community to suffer 385 years to construct a plausible proof.<br />After that, we see how Euler proved the case when n = 3. Then Sophie Germain prove it, inspired by Euler, for the Germain prime numbers. This eliminated most of the cases, yet there still infinitely many cases to check. The book does not go into technicalities, but you can enjoy reading about the backgrounds of some of brightest mathematicians of the 19th century.<br />Then comes some account on cryptography, as being the direct application to Number Theory, followed by the story of how Andrew Wiles, the most famous mathematician of our time, came to prove this theorem.<br />It proved to be even a harder task. It involved some modern up-to-date mathematics, some fields of Number Theory called: &quot;Elleptic Curves&quot; and &quot;Modular Forms.&quot;<br />And to conclude I would like to say that I think any person with some understanding of the notion of mathematics may be very able to enjoy it as much as I did. If you want an introduction to this &quot;mysterious&quot; discipline, this book would provide you the best read.

B00008S2VG|5.0|Madonna has proven with her last two albums, 1998's \\"Ray of Light\\" and 2000's \\"Music\\" that she doesn't want to repeat herself. Everything is about forging ahead, exploring new sounds, writing challenging songs, and \\"American Life\\" continues in that vein. It is an exquisite piece of work, more consistant and better sequenced than \\"Music,\\" a brilliant album in its own right but \\"American Life\\" digs deeper, hits harder, and is generally a more rewarding album. From the electro-pop-rap of the title track to the haunting finale \\"Easy Ride,\\" Madonna's message is clear: she is taking a long, hard look at herself, flaws and all, and not about to give up. Aside from those two songs, other greats include \\"Nobody Knows Me,\\" a dance gem with some great hooks, \\"Nothing Fails,\\" a truly inspiring song and the James Bond theme \\"Die Another Day,\\" which works seamlessly into the album (it has a slightly better mix than what was released to radio). \\"Mother and Father\\" is intensely personal and musically challenging, as is \\"I'm So Stupid,\\" which has an exciting, devil-may-care psychadelic rock feel. Perhaps best of all is \\"Hollywood,\\" a smooth pop gem which is sure to be a smash. Madonna delivers a challenging piece of work at a time when many pop artists are just coasting, giving us more of the same. \\"American Life\\" is worthy of many listens, and has much to offer.
B000002J29|5.0|I agree with most reviewers here that Seconds Out is an amazing recording. I just wanted to clarify something that has always caused confusion. <BR>     The original LP states &quot;All Drums Chester except: Robbery, Assault and Battery - keyboard solo Phil, Firth of Fifth - Phil &amp; Chester, The Musical Box - Chester &amp; Phil, Supper's Ready - Apocalypse 9/8 Chester &amp; Phil, Cinema Show- Bill Bruford/Phil keyboard solo, Los Endos- Phil &amp; Chester&quot; <BR>    What that means is that Phil played drums DURING the keyboard solo in Robbery, Assault and Battery -- NOT that he played the actual keyboard solo. The same with Cinema Show.
B00005Y228|4.0|With as much MTV TRL disposable-hit backlash animosity that flies around these days, and as much smarmy pop-explosion forecasting muttered about, it'd seem neigh-impossible to expect artists to sustain a career from top-40 processed and packaged hits. <br />Then there's Kylie Minogue, world pop star and multi-million album mover for over a decade, cheerily delivering shiny disco fun mixed with video savvy. Fever, her breakout record for the States, features a dozen cuts of high polish glam dance, from hit single \\"Can't Get You Out of My Head\\" (as infectious a hook and La La La chorus as you'll find) to dizzyingly delightful \\"Love at First Sight,\\" tweaking filtered strings and light guitar with - wait for it - an infectious hook sighing \\"everything went from wrong to right, the music you were playing really blew my mind.\\" <br />And so on. Two more notable cuts, breezy opener \\"More More More,\\" and the album's best trick \\"Come In To My World\\" stripped down to a minimal techno beat and layers of Kylie cooing on the romantic title line. It's a credit to her production team that they're mostly able to sustain four minute onslaughts of glittery beats, bleeps and catchy choruses over twelve tracks - that's a lot of candy in 45 minutes. If she errs, it's when \\"Give It To Me\\" goes for edgier lyrics that doesn't mesh with her sugary voice, and a helium-high pitched \\"Burning Up\\" pushes into a simple Kylie acoustical closing ballad.<br />Minor quibbles; Fever freely offers unapologetic simple charm for those that want it.
B00008S2VH|5.0|\\"American Life\\" is an interesting mix of electronica & folk.  It's very stripped down and simplistic, yet it's also layered and complex.  I would have to say the title song is probably the least likable track on the record.  Everyone seems to be panning this album at the moment but I think that's because the critics either hate Madonna or expect too much from her.  This is a different 'sound' we're used to hearing from her and critics (and some fans) just want the same old thing.  I think people are just too concerned with any messages Madonna is trying to convey. If you care about messages then, to me, this record pretty much points out our obsessions with celebrity, commercialism, and ourselves.  It's also pretty spiritual: material things don't matter--love does. I think the better songs on the album are \\"Love Profusion\\", \\"Nothing Fails\\", \\"X-Static Process\\", and \\"Easy Ride\\".  This album may suffer the same fate as her 1992 album Erotica, critically shunned and later held up and embraced as one of her 'better' albums.  Listen to it a few times and let it grow on you, you'll see it's hidden boldness, imaginative curves, and bitter honesty.  I think this is one of her best albums.  Refreshing after so many manufactured bands/acts, and teens who think they know all about life.  The Limited Edition is identical to the 'explicit' version with the exception of the packaging: a nice black, white, and red cardboard-like picture box, a different picture on the disc, a foldout poster, and a sheet of Madonna 'stamps' which are just stickers with the album cover on them.    UPDATE:  As 2006 approaches and after the recent release of \\"Confessions on a Dance Floor\\", I decide to revisit \\"American Life\\" 2 1/2 years later.  With all the reviews concerning \\"Confessions...\\" bashing this album, often referring to it as \\"much-maligned\\" and \\"overly-political\\", I thought I should call the reviewers out on their mistakes.  THERE IS NOT ONE POLITICAL MESSAGE ON THIS ALBUM, PERIOD.  Listenand see.  WHY IT FAILED: This album failed because of marketing, timing, a weak lead-single, Madonna's personal opinions, and critics who outright lied in their reviews.  Strike one: the US was about to go into Iraq when this album came out and Madonna was against the war (and vocal about it).  Strike two: the \\"American Life\\" video, NOT THE SONG, was the only political statement connected to this album (and the video was pulled before release, and later leaked).  Strike three: the song \\"American Life\\" is the weakest song on the album and it's release as the first single pretty-much sealed the fate of the album as a whole.  Other factors: the title of the album, I believe, was a bad move.  Since 9/11, anything with the word \\"American\\" on it was/is subjected to extreme criticism and scrutiny.  It's a no-no to use the A-word in your work unless you're a country-singer, a religious-singer, or both.  Another bad move was the Patty Hearst/Che Guevara album cover and artwork.  People see that cover and think it's aggressive and combative.  The critics claimed the album was rife with political messages, Kabbalistic preachings, and over-use of the vocoder.  Well, if they had actually heard the album, they would know that there's no political messages at all.  There may be some Kabbalah messages in it, but they sound so common-sense and Christian/Catholic/Buddhist--everything!, that it's not so clear.  It's really generically spiritual, not explicitly Kabbalah or any other religion.  As for the vocoder (sound a little robot-like) was only used on 2 or three songs.  What's funny is that Madonna uses it more often on \\"Confessions on a Dance Floor\\" and the critics love it!  This is a fantastic Madonna album that will be appreciated over time.  It's also the closest thing to acoustic-Madonna we've ever seen.  It's great to hear some more guitars in her music and less synthesizers.  \\"American Life\\" is an album that should not be overlooked because of a bad cover and silly misconceptions.
B00008S2VH|5.0|This album is one of Madonna's most creative. It is very good.<br />What I want to focus on in this review is the Limited Edition itself, and not the music. <br />The American Life Limited Edition is presented in a 2-piece telescoping box that is covered in White &quot;leatherette&quot; fabric and silk-screened in Black and Red ink. The inside of the box top is lined in red paper and the bottom is covered in Black &quot;linen&quot; fabric.<br />Inside, you will find the Enhanced CD (which I am almost sure is identical to the standard explicit version), you will also find a 2-sided 23&quot;x35&quot; poster, as well as a postage-sized Madonna stap sheet.<br />This item is definately for collectors! One day it will become very rare! <br />On the other hand, if you are not a huge Madonna fan, then the extras are not worth it for your money. But be sure to buy the standard version. If not, you are missing out on a great album!
B00008S2VG|3.0|Madonna used to brilliant and I don't mean back in the 80's I mean up until her last album. While she has blasted into the techno-pop phase of her career. Songs of previous works such as &quot;Ray of Light&quot; and &quot;Don't Tell Me&quot; still gave you access to grooves and a sense of relation. We all want to find a voice and be able to groove in the key of love. But on American Life Madonna refuses to let us party. She turns this album into about her and that's it she raps about her materlism is utter sardonic bitterness and it comes off as cold and lifeless. Just as Michael Jackson forgot how to groove and let us party Madonna is forgetting her roots are in the dance and turning her career and albums into self loathing works of tripe. She redeems herself with the balzing song &quot;Hollywood&quot;, Mirwais bleeps and guitar are set on top of a thumping bass that boosts the listener up to dancefloor highlights as &quot;Express Yourself&quot; and &quot;Like a Prayer&quot;. The album misses that dance floor groove, I am all for music as a form of self exploration but where is the music? She managed it all so well on her last two techno driven discs. Only a few songs salvage this cd from average, but when the songs are there that grab you, you notice the Madonna of old. The one who wanted to see ya dance and get into the groove!

B00008OSD3|3.0|The Star Trek franchise (at around 10 movies and 5 series) is like farmland. It once produced bountiful and rich scripts, but has been so over harvested that story lines are increasingly stunted. Indeed, Star Trek Nemesis seems more like a rehash of the Wrath of Khan film, with additional plot elements from the TV series mixed in.<br />Without revealing too much of the movie, this film has a Federation's archrival suffering a crisis stemming from a mining planet (sound familiar?). A duplicate of Data comes into being and is subsequently used against the crew. From that point on, there are secret crew clones, mind melds, ship versus ship battles, the clumsily staged \\"death\\" of a major character who sacrifices their life to save the Enterprise, and so forth. All of these plot elements have been taken from earlier films or TV shows, reworked and repackaged.<br />Nemesis is clearly an attempt to replicate the successful Wrath of Khan movie. Unfortunately, the franchise has so focused on science fiction rather than traditional story elements, that the character identification and sentimentality that made up the original series, is absent for casual viewers. When the original Enterprise was blow-up in an earlier film or Spock died, the sense of loss that the director was trying to project, seemed tangible. Now, with a shiny new ship for each film or a multitude of duplicate crewmembers, it all seems contrived. <br />From an action standpoint, Nemesis is better than previous two or three films and is entertaining to watch. Nevertheless, this movie is a shadow of what the franchise once was. Perhaps if the producers let this series lay fallow for several years, it may bear fruit again.
B00008S2VH|5.0|Madonna?s newest album, American Life, explores a great deal of emotional depth and is significant for her message, rather than just her music, this time around.  The title track throbs and bumps with a new-world sensibility crashing into the techno-pop of old (read: just about 5 years ago!) that produces a jarring, but interesting effect.  While some have complained that the song seems disjointed, the point here seems to have been lost on some:  the song is about being disjointed from one?s life.  What happens when you finally have what you thought you wanted?  Where do you go from here?  What new horizons are left?  Many have skewered Madonna on this song because she is wealthy and therefore is asking Argentina to indeed cry for her.  But, Madonna?s message seems more complex: how can one truly know about the dangers and pitfalls of materialism and beauty unless you have achieved those goals?  It isn?t surprising in this context that people would have trouble with the message, after all ? if they didn?t, there would be no point for the song or the aptly titled album.<br /> Hollywood, the next track, is the catchiest on the record.  This guaranteed radio-hit is sure to become a top 40 single.  The hook and melody suggest that one is actually driving in the famed city, counterpointing lyrics that belie the happiness that fame and excess bring.  It?s reminiscent of an earlier Madonna, an almost 80?s-like song brought into the new millennium.  Fans who desponded during her Drowned World tour for the lack of ?early? material from her career should be happy here.  This is what Madonna does best: a sugary-sweet pop hit that just begs to be remixed onto the dance floor for us to grind to.<br /> I?m So Stupid, is another crashing and grinding anthem against materialism.  Mirwais is in his element here, creating a sonic piledriver that rages to be set free against the restraints you can almost feel he has put on it.  It?s melancholy-yet-angry-and-defiant chorus leaves you with little doubt that Madonna can still create good pop art.<br /> The next song, Love Profusion, is where this new ?unmaterial? girl sounds very 60?s ? and almost as some have claimed ? like Joni Mitchell.  It?s a fascinating sound, and not one you would think Madonna would head into despite the folky music she demonstrated on Music.  The combination of guitar and new-age funk really do seem to go together.  And it?s suprisingly good.  It makes you wonder why no one has tried this sound before.  It?s works so well, that Madonna tries two more combinations in Intervention (dedicated to her son) and X-Static Process.  <br /> Nobody Knows Me is another solid pop effort that has another effective hook into the song.  Catchy but with attitude, one can almost picture Madonna flipping her finger at the critics and the paparazzi.  It?s simultaneously trendy yet classic ? again, pure Madonna.<br /> The gorgeous Nothing Fails is really the centerpiece of the album.  A lush ballad that begins almost shy and playful moves into surprisingly deep and revealing territory.  It is a testiment to love ? pure, unconditional, and beautiful.  It is the peak that Madonna seems to now be striving for.  Much has been made of the surprise gospel choir at the end of the song, and with good reason.  The parallels to Like a Prayer are inevitable, but really are incongruent here.  The choir is here for a deeper emotional effect, rather than one that panders to simple gospel-loving, hand-clapping faux-religion.  It leaves one breathless, and inspired.<br /> Mother and Father is perhaps the scene-stealer and show-stopper on the album.  Tooting wistfully in a little girl?s voice, Madonna releases her inner child for all to see.  (Ironically, the child must like techno?)  Contrasting an almost before-and-after picture of life the time her mother died, you would think the song would be dark and brooding.  An ?Oh, Father? of the new millennium, as it were.  But you almost get the sense that there iscatharsis here: a solitary last glance back at the pain and confusion that literally made Madonna, well?Madonna.  The song points fingers, but doesn?t in a mean way.  You can see the forgiveness coming out of the hurt ? perhaps time has finally began to heal this wound. <br /> <BR>     Die Another Day, the soundtrack song from the James Bond film of the same name, actually fits in here.  Rather than just an abrupt, rambling piece about defiance, the transition here actually makes sense.  It?s the grown up Madonna finding out there is more to life.  By the time the final track, Easy Ride comes along, the album appears to almost come seamlessly together.<br />     That?s what makes this one of the more fascinating albums of Madonna?s career ? this is the first album she has produced in years that seems to have a continuous theme to it that doesn?t seem forced or made for promotions? sake since Like A Prayer.  The maturity in her voice, along with the genuine risks she seems to be taking on the album, make this arguably one of the finest of her career.  Critics and naysayers may cringe that there are no Express Yourself-like smashes on the album to blow away the Aguileras and the Spears waiting to take over her throne.  However, the beauty here is that she does do exactly that ? and with subtlety and finesse, among lush guitars and smattering acoustics that seem timeless.  This ?kinder, gentler? Madonna may be more subtle, but it?s a transformation that is both welcome and endearing.  You can?t help but wonder what will come next.

This movie is about this lady having this son, who has a face its hard to explain but its not like our faces, its different. And he goes to this camp and meets this girl, oh! I dont wanna give it away lol! You'll have to see it yourself. Buy it!
B00008S2VG|5.0|Madonna's newest album, American Life, explores a great deal of emotional depth and is significant for her message, rather than just her music, this time around.  The title track throbs and bumps with a new-world sensibility crashing into the techno-pop of old (read: just about 5 years ago!) that produces a jarring, but interesting effect.  While some have complained that the song seems disjointed, the point here seems to have been lost on some:  the song is about being disjointed from one's life.  What happens when you finally have what you thought you wanted?  Where do you go from here?  What new horizons are left?  Many have skewered Madonna on this song because she is wealthy and therefore is asking Argentina to indeed cry for her.  But, Madonna's message seems more complex: how can one truly know about the dangers and pitfalls of materialism and beauty unless you have achieved those goals?  It isn't surprising in this context that people would have trouble with the message, after all - if they didn't, there would be no point for the song or the aptly titled album.<br /> Hollywood, the next track, is the catchiest on the record.  This guaranteed radio-hit is sure to become a top 40 single.  The hook and melody suggest that one is actually driving in the famed city, counterpointing lyrics that belie the happiness that fame and excess bring.  It's reminiscent of an earlier Madonna, an almost 80's-like song brought into the new millennium.  Fans who desponded during her Drowned World tour for the lack of `early' material from her career should be happy here.  This is what Madonna does best: a sugary-sweet pop hit that just begs to be remixed onto the dance floor for us to grind to.<br /> I'm So Stupid, is another crashing and grinding anthem against materialism.  Mirwais is in his element here, creating a sonic piledriver that rages to be set free against the restraints you can almost feel he has put on it.  It's melancholy-yet-angry-and-defiant chorus leaves you with little doubt that Madonna can still create good pop art.<br /> The next song, Love Profusion, is where this new \\"unmaterial\\" girl sounds very 60's - and almost as some have claimed - like Joni Mitchell.  It's a fascinating sound, and not one you would think Madonna would head into despite the folky music she demonstrated on Music.  The combination of guitar and new-age funk really do seem to go together.  And it's suprisingly good.  It makes you wonder why no one has tried this sound before.  It's works so well, that Madonna tries two more combinations in Intervention (dedicated to her son) and X-Static Process.  <br /> Nobody Knows Me is another solid pop effort that has another effective hook into the song.  Catchy but with attitude, one can almost picture Madonna flipping her finger at the critics and the paparazzi.  It's simultaneously trendy yet classic - again, pure Madonna.<br /> The gorgeous Nothing Fails is really the centerpiece of the album.  A lush ballad that begins almost shy and playful moves into surprisingly deep and revealing territory.  It is a testiment to love - pure, unconditional, and beautiful.  It is the peak that Madonna seems to now be striving for.  Much has been made of the surprise gospel choir at the end of the song, and with good reason.  The parallels to Like a Prayer are inevitable, but really are incongruent here.  The choir is here for a deeper emotional effect, rather than one that panders to simple gospel-loving, hand-clapping faux-religion.  It leaves one breathless, and inspired.<br /> Mother and Father is perhaps the scene-stealer and show-stopper on the album.  Tooting wistfully in a little girl's voice, Madonna releases her inner child for all to see.  (Ironically, the child must like techno...)  Contrasting an almost before-and-after picture of life the time her mother died, you would think the song would be dark and brooding.  An \\"Oh, Father\\" of the new millennium, as it were.  But you almost get the sense that thereis catharsis here: a solitary last glance back at the pain and confusion that literally made Madonna, well...Madonna.  The song points fingers, but doesn't in a mean way.  You can see the forgiveness coming out of the hurt - perhaps time has finally began to heal this wound. <br /> <BR>     Die Another Day, the soundtrack song from the James Bond film of the same name, actually fits in here.  Rather than just an abrupt, rambling piece about defiance, the transition here actually makes sense.  It's the grown up Madonna finding out there is more to life.  By the time the final track, Easy Ride comes along, the album appears to almost come seamlessly together.<br />     That's what makes this one of the more fascinating albums of Madonna's career - this is the first album she has produced in years that seems to have a continuous theme to it that doesn't seem forced or made for promotions' sake since Like A Prayer.  The maturity in her voice, along with the genuine risks she seems to be taking on the album, make this arguably one of the finest of her career.  Critics and naysayers may cringe that there are no Express Yourself-like smashes on the album to blow away the Aguileras and the Spears waiting to take over her throne.  However, the beauty here is that she does do exactly that - and with subtlety and finesse, among lush guitars and smattering acoustics that seem timeless.  This `kinder, gentler' Madonna may be more subtle, but it's a transformation that is both welcome and endearing.  You can't help but wonder what will come next.
B00008S2VH|5.0|Marketing guys at Madonna's team must be working very good in trying to sintonize the wonderful mature girl between the actual trends of electronic dance music and the top ten club hits such as Cher's. Anyway this is a great great album. A lot of rythmn and madonna taste. Just a little less Vocoder would have been better, but you know, time is an issue for everyone and technology can do miracles, sometimes. Wonderful record! DJ CATTANEO.

This guaranteed radio-hit is sure to become a top 40 single. It's a fascinating sound, and not one you would think Madonna would head into despite the folky music she demonstrated on Music.  The combination of guitar and new-age funk really do seem to go together.  And it's suprisingly good.  It makes you wonder why no one has tried this sound before.  It's works so well, that Madonna tries two more combinations in Intervention (dedicated to her son) and X-Static Process.  <br /> Nobody Knows Me is another solid pop effort that has another effective hook into the song.  Catchy but with attitude, one can almost picture Madonna flipping her finger at the critics and the paparazzi.  It's simultaneously trendy yet classic - again, pure Madonna.<br /> The gorgeous Nothing Fails is really the centerpiece of the album.  A lush ballad that begins almost shy and playful moves into surprisingly deep and revealing territory.  It is a testiment to love - pure, unconditional, and beautiful.  It is the peak that Madonna seems to now be striving for.  Much has been made of the surprise gospel choir at the end of the song, and with good reason.  The parallels to Like a Prayer are inevitable, but really are incongruent here.  The choir is here for a deeper emotional effect, rather than one that panders to simple gospel-loving, hand-clapping faux-religion.  It leaves one breathless, and inspired.<br /> Mother and Father is perhaps the scene-stealer and show-stopper on the album.  Tooting wistfully in a little girl's voice, Madonna releases her inner child for all to see.  (Ironically, the child must like techno...)  Contrasting an almost before-and-after picture of life the time her mother died, you would think the song would be dark and brooding.  An \\"Oh, Father\\" of the new millennium, as it were.  But you almost get the sense that thereis catharsis here: a solitary last glance back at the pain and confusion that literally made Madonna, well...Madonna.  The song points fingers, but doesn't in a mean way.  You can see the forgiveness coming out of the hurt - perhaps time has finally began to heal this wound. <br /> <BR>     Die Another Day, the soundtrack song from the James Bond film of the same name, actually fits in here.  Rather than just an abrupt, rambling piece about defiance, the transition here actually makes sense.  It's the grown up Madonna finding out there is more to life.  By the time the final track, Easy Ride comes along, the album appears to almost come seamlessly together.<br />     That's what makes this one of the more fascinating albums of Madonna's career - this is the first album she has produced in years that seems to have a continuous theme to it that doesn't seem forced or made for promotions' sake since Like A Prayer.  The maturity in her voice, along with the genuine risks she seems to be taking on the album, make this arguably one of the finest of her career.  Critics and naysayers may cringe that there are no Express Yourself-like smashes on the album to blow away the Aguileras and the Spears waiting to take over her throne.  However, the beauty here is that she does do exactly that - and with subtlety and finesse, among lush guitars and smattering acoustics that seem timeless.  This `kinder, gentler' Madonna may be more subtle, but it's a transformation that is both welcome and endearing.  You can't help but wonder what will come next.

B00005OAIE|5.0|I read all the negative reviews directed towards Room for Squares and thought to myself, &quot;these folks must be missing something!&quot;  John's writing and musical styles are not tailored for the 21st century norm of loud, complicated, and tacky songs overcrowded with attempts to sell sell sell.  What his music does provide is a step away from the noisy rush of our society to explore the winding emotional rollercoaster that engulfs our mid-20's.  Each song specifically targets a time in life where one steps back and evaluates &quot;where am i going?&quot;  If you are looking for the answer, then you will be disappointed.  But if you can appreciate the question, then you will love this album.
0679735909|1.0|*Possession* is a renowned work, earning awards and critical praise. However, as a graduate student in literature increasingly disinterested in academia, I found Byatt's work to be problematic. The book is clearly an exhibition--it features so many literary forms, that it almost becomes bothersome--but where it falls short is in its characterizations. The primary cast is upper-middle to upper-class scholars, academics, all white, and all &quot;possessed&quot; (or &quot;obsessed&quot;) in some way exclusively with a literary figure of the past. To cite Forster, I contend then that Byatt's characters are flatter than round, more aloof than accessible. That is, even as a graduate student, I had difficulty identifying with any of them. Their drives and motivations are also difficult to relate to, further distancing the characters from the reader. It is a complete love story, but I should imagine that the reader seeking romance could easily find a more accessible and enjoyable read elsewhere. Moreover, as anyone who has read novels and watched their movie adaptations will attest, the movies rarely live up to the expectations created through reading a novel. With that, I caution also those who see the movie and expect the book to be similar to rest in their casual enjoyment with a 2-hour sit in front of their TVs.

I recomended it to my mother who continues to recomend it to her friends everyday. Go out and buy it right now, at least thats what Becky Bloomwood (main character) would say!
B00008DDXC|2.0|In a nutshell: Chris Colombus can't direct for toffee. This is a dreadful rendering of a damn good read.<br />Acting: By and large, dreadful - as you would expect from twelve year olds, but very disappointing from the support cast of adult, eminence grises of the British acting establishment.<br />Coherence: poor - no one can blame Colombus for being unimaginative in his transfer of the book to the screen (to do otherwise would be to be crucified by a lynch mob of 9 year olds), but the transfer at least needs to make sense. This does not. Much of the plot was explained retrospectively by helpful, heavy-handed soliloquy, and even then wasn't awfully clear. And that's to someone who's read the book.<br />Dramatic tension: non-existent - The final showdown, which should have been edge of seat-gripping stuff, was simply dull: We have no empathy for Harry, no sense of who the villain really is (can't Voldemort do better than manifest himself in a hologram of an effete 16 year old?), what is at stake, why Ron Weasly's sister is there, and what the point of the Phoenix is (other than as a pretty ... plot device to dig Harry out of a sticky situation. Rowling's books are real page-turning Ripping Yarns, which are why they've sold so well. Colombus failed totally to import this onto this second film (the first was much better).<br />Finally - and this is partly Rowling's fault, as she wrote the books this way - it's terribly formulaic, and in execution is derivative of a number of other classic B-grade movies (ET, Raiders of the Lost Ark and Star Wars amongst them).<br />Not destined for great things come Oscar time, methinks.

B00006JJ1O|4.0|I first head their music during the summer of 2001, my friends from Moscow brought me a copy of their debut CD. The lyrics were offcourse Russian, their voices do not distinguish them from other Russian pop singers, or pop singers in general, although the duo nature does provide a benevolent effect.<br />As I was listening to the music in the car, I began to notice things...Not the feeble, sometimes randomized and primitively taylored lyrics, but interesting elements in the production. Their producer Ivan Something [the guy who writes/produces the music, the guy behind the drum machine and Roland] practically carries the group on his music.<br />The melodies are surprisingly enjoyable, at times more trancy than dancy and it seems as if the produced is just restrained by the pop nature of the group...Another aspect of the music I despise are the samples chosen. They are a breed of the archaic dance formula, bright synths, ambient strings, heavy kicks and 4x4 hats. Listen to mixes by Oakenfold and Max Graham to see the more professional side of dance/trance electronica.<br />In conclusion, there are about 4 or 5 good songs, but I admit that I cannot stand to listen to them anymore, beacause I've had too much. The formula works, every teenage Russian girl I know is crazy about them [here in the US atleast] and all teenage girls are pretty much the same so...

B000002LPH|5.0|I am very picky in my musical taste! Why is this CD out of print? I have listened to this recording, literaly near a thousand times. Mr Harrison's eclectic, spiritual sound that is prevelant on all his recordings (Including his last \\"Brainwashed\\") never sounded better than it does here. \\"Soft Hearted Hana\\" is amazing. \\"Not Guilty\\" which was originaly recorded for the \\"Let it be\\" sessions, finally finds it way to album form. How could the beatles not have used this? \\"Blow away\\" is george having fun, I wish he made more music like this. \\"Here comes the moon\\" his answer to the beatles \\"Here comes the sun\\" is a more than adequate follow up. \\"Your love is forever\\" is my personal favorite. What your true nature is and how to find lasting peace. The basic premise is concept-free spirituality based on seeking your true nature in deep awareness. B000002NJS|4.0|Let's make this 4.32 stars...to be as fair and accurate as possible;)<BR>This was actually the first Madonna album i bought, and though i was expecting it to be interesting, i was very surprised by the emotional depth and musical exploration it showcased for the masses. First off, i think that many people should be grateful to Madonna for showing this more esoteric music for the commerical market, getting more people to be interested in \\"the underground\\". But let's get to the album itself, which i think is a great triumph for Madonna on many levels, as well as a musical treat.<BR>1/ Drowned World/Substitute For Love: from the moment you hear this song, you know the album is going to carry some sort of heavy weight. Perhaps, like most of the album, there is something Slightly pretentious, let captivating. It's a good song and was a single with a frightening video.<BR>2/ Swim: perhaps one of the most cliche-sounding songs on the album, with slihgtly clunky yet sincere lyrics...and it spite of this, it isn't a bad song. it has William Orbit's trademark \\"wah-wah\\" drifting, guitar, which does very much evoke images of liquids.<BR>3/ Ray Of Light: undoubtedly the biggest hit from the album, with its frantic video to match its equally frantic beats. It is very listenable and well remixed.<BR>4/ Candy Perfume Girl: A cool and edgy song with bizarre lyrics and loud guitar, this song is one of the highlights of the album.<BR>5/ Skin: a fragmented, trippy, and engagingly disturbing Eastern-tinged techno song...its lyrics are desperate and dificult to ignore. the length of this song is part of its appeal to the listener.<BR>6/ Nothing Really Matters: One of the catchiest songs on the album; uptempo, yet relaxing. Melancholy, yet uplifting. And yes, there is something somewhat pretentious about these lyrics as well, but we can forgive her, cuz it's such a memorable song. The video for it is one of her best.<BR>7/ Sky Fits Heaven: A fragmented tale of her personal \\"revelation\\", the lyrics are once again questionable, but the production is sweeping and superb.<BR>8/ Shanti/Ashtangi: Arguabley pretentious, but it is my personal favourite on the album. It is an Indian-dance chillout song, sung entirely in Sanskrit from ancient texts, and set to music by none other than Madonna and William Orbit.<BR>9/ Frozen: This song and its striking video, were the first single off the album, and it's difficult to forget the longing lyrics seamlessly blended with the eastern and the techno, and the visuals, if you saw the video when it came out, as i did.<BR>10/ The Power Of Goodbye: Perhaps the most openly mournful song on the album, it's simple yet compelling and catchy. Also a single, with a lonely-looking video.<BR>11/ To Have and Not To Hold: This song is beautiful and heart-wrenching, with a drifty-sound.<BR>12/ Little Star: This is Madonna's sweet tribute to her then-recently-born daughter. It's a new side of Madonna, coupled with a gorgeous arrangement and tune. It's one of her most memorable songs.<BR>13/ Mer Girl: This song, which somehow manages to be frightening, pretentious, regretful, angry, contemplative, and yet sincere all at once, ends the album on a sobering, if not chilling note. It deals with her feelings of her mothers death at cryptically epic proportions.<br />Although we may miss the more rebelloious madona, it's nice that she's happy and willing to show us a side of her previously unrevealed. this album is refreshing and reccomended for every music lover's collection.

That is the problem with being on a best seller list like Tolle now is, the book is being read by people who normally wouldn't read something like this and \\"give it a shot cause it's kind of popular now\\" and are faced with talk on \\"Ego, trancending mind chatter, enlightenment, how the past/future are only mental creations etc.\\" This is a book for people who are willing to take a moment to understand the premise...your true nature is beyond body, mind identification/constructs. B00006F7S4|5.0|I have been a casual fan of Beck since the Mellow Gold days, but I never actually bought one of his albums.  However after all of the praise for &quot;Sea Change&quot; I felt somehow compelled to pick it up.  Definately a good choice on my behalf.  Very mellow album with a very musical appeal.  Mr. Hanson's sense of harmony and intrinsically palatable melodies is commendable.  This is an album that will spark thoughts about topics largely unrelated to whatever topic the song is referencing.  Beck's lyrics are almost unneccessary...the music uses the vocals as fodder for a highly cultivated end product.<br />Additionally, the sonics on this album are absolutely fantasic.  Beck is an audiophile himself, and he shows it by offering this album in three distinct versions.  The standard CD also features the HDCD fomat, which is a slightly improved 20 bit (compared to 16) recording where the upper frequencies definately have more life to them.<br />The other CD features the third version, SACD (Super Audio CD), a very high resolution digital format invented by Sony and Phillips.  Unfortunately,  since I haven't bought my SACD player yet, I was unable to demo this option.  But I do have an HDCD Receiver, so I was able to hear that version.<br />The Bottom line is that Beck has once again managed to both evolve as a musician and entertain (albeit slowly and gently)us at the same time.  Highly Recomended (Go buy some nice speakers!)

0198534469|5.0|I tried to learn complex analysis from Ahlfors, I wouldn't recommend you try it although it is a good book. The problem is there are certain subtleties in complex variables that are NOT obvious. There are few authors of math books that remember that we do not know these subtleties. I could go on a tirade about the general state of math literature for hours, but my only remark here is that in my view most authors seem to be trying to impress someone other than the students, maybe other professors ? Anyhow, this book is a definite departure from this nonsense. There are 12 chapters each with many exercises. The first couple of chapters have over forty and since I try to do them all, well ... If you read this book carefully and do the execises you WILL know this subject. You could teach it. You don't see Thm 1.2.3.5.8 followed by Proof. What you do see is a clear presentation of the ideas with PICTURES and EXPLANATIONS that you can understand, of course you really find out about that \\"understand\\" part when you get to the exercises. The biggest problem I had was getting out of the old way of thinking and into a more geometric way of thinking. Couldn't recommend it more highly. Another author who writes to teach is Victor Bryant. His book Yet Another Introduction to Analysis is great for a highschool senior or 1st year college. (He is with me on the state of math literature.) Also, Hans Schwerdtfeger's book Geometry of Complex Numbers goes well with Needham and is very cheap ! I'm surprised Needham didn't include it in the bibliography. It's a little gem and covers some of the same material.

B00006IUL7|4.0|Hollywood seems to have a love affair with remakes. A few years back it was hip to remake French films, then it was film versions of old TV shows, and every year there seems to be a \\"Sequelitis\\" epidemic in multiplexes worldwide. But INSOMNIA offers a Hollywood rarity: This is a remake of a NORWEGIAN movie.<BR>While my opening comments don't offer much hope for the film, INSOMNIA is actually a great movie once you get into it. Starring Oscar winners Al Pacino, Robin Williams and Hilary Swank, executive produced by Steven Soderbergh and George Clooney and directed by Christopher Nolan director of the vastly overrated MEMENTO, INSOMNIA is a compelling mystery thriller.<BR>When cop Will Dormer (Pacino) witnesses the murder of his partner, the prime suspect is mystery writer Walter Finch (Williams). But while Finch appears accommodating to the police, chronic insomniac Dormer finds himself receiving taunting calls from Finch in the middle of the night. Dormer's investigation leads him to a remote Alaskan town which never sees nightfall during the spring/summer seasons where he is partnered with local cop Ellie Burr (Hillary Swank). But with the combination of the continued threats from his unseen nemesis and the stress of the investigation, Dormer's sleeping disorder is wearing him down and disorientating him, making him an easier target.<BR>Like MEMENTO, INSOMNIA is full of twists and is beautifully photographed. But thankfully unlike it, INSOMNIA has a plot that makes sense and keeps the viewer glued to the screen; but it is the strong characterisations by Pacino and Williams that make their cat-and-mouse game utterly compelling. I haven't seen the Norwegian version, but as far as remakes go its probably a pretty safe bet that INSOMNIA is in the upper ranks.

She listens to Andrea Bottcelli and collects ceramic roosters. Take her drugs away and within two hours she'd be defecating on her lawn and threatening relatives with scalding cookware. Being that is was released by Madonna, however, critics can't help but make jabs at their favorite pop punching-bag.<br />This album is quite strong, with trimmed-down arrangements and folk-driven sensibilities.  True, this album is not chalk-full of radio-friendly pop nuggets, but what it lacks in Top 40 appeal is balanced by interesting arrangements and, moreover, subtlety.  Madonna's vocals are the best I've heard in her career - smooth, mature, and utilized to the best of its abilities.  Her lyrics can strike one at first as naff (\\"Mother & Father\\") but, after a few lessons, one can begin to understand just how well thought-out they are (as she harkens back to her childhood confusion, she utilizes a more chidlike lyric).  <br />The songs complement each other well, and it's been quite some time since I've heard a Madonna album sound so cohesive.  Even \\"Die Another Day\\" is given depth and a new perspective by its addition to the album.<br />\\"American Life\\" is an achievement for Madonna, regardless of the critics' bashings.  It reflects the Madonna of today and doesn't try to opt for the path down which many other artists right now (white-washed R&B and same ol' same ol' producers) are treading.  It's a grower, mind you, but it sits in your skull and mulls about and that's exactly what I want from an album.  She's done it again, in my book.

B0000024SI|5.0|With the opening chords of &quot;Like A Rolling Stone&quot;, Bob Dylan shook the rock music world, both lyrically and musically back to its roots and forward into a new universe.  This album is without a doubt one of the 10 most essential albums in the history of rock music, not to mention pop music in general.  From the simple monotonous organ line provided by Al Kooper and signature guitar riff from Robbie Robertson on &quot;Like A Rolling Stone&quot;, Dylan wraps his snarling, piercing vocals around some of the most recognized lyrics ever written.  &quot;From A Buick 6&quot; shows his synthesis of blues and rock with nods to Muddy Waters, Chuck Berry and Bo Diddley.  A folkie? Hah! This is a man reinventing rock'n'roll before our very ears.  <br />&quot;Tombstone Blues&quot;, &quot;Just Like Tom Thumb's Blues&quot; and the title track show that Dylan could recall the blues masters and beat that musical form into a new idiom that stood musical convention on its ear, while &quot;Queen Jane Approximately&quot; ushered in a new dynamic on the state of affairs of the heart.  Over 35 years later, this is an album that will astound, confound and flat out rock your socks off while showing the folk music world that their craft was becoming irrelevant.  Never has an artist made such a bold statement that would set the tone for not only his peers but for those to follow.  Years down the road, one can still delight in the sheer mastery of Dylan's talent and his not-too-subtle showing off of his influences.  It is one of the few albums that truly shows an artist at his creative best while paying all the right dues to what came before.<br />This is one of the most daring and innovative albums ever recorded.  Your music collection is empty if you do not own this album.

0156027321|5.0|It is not so much that The Life of Pi, is particularly moving (although it is). It isn't even so much that it is written with language that is both delicate and sturdy all at once (which it is, as well). And it's certainly not that Yann Martel's vision filled passages are so precise that you begin to feel the salt water on your skin (even though they are). It is that, like Bohjalian and Byatt and all of the great Houdini's of the literary world, in the last few moments of your journey ' after you've felt the emotions, endured the moments of heartache, yearned for the resolution of the characters' struggle ' that you realize the book is not what you thought it was. The story transforms, instantly, and forever.<br />And in those last few chapters, you suddenly realize that the moral has changed as well.<br />You feel Martel's words lingering, suggesting, and you find yourself wondering whether you are his atheist who takes the deathbed leap of faith ' hoping for white light and love? Or the agnostic who , in trying to stay true to his reasonable self, explains the mysteries of life and death in only scientific terms, lacking imagination to the end, and, essentially, missing the better story?<br />There is no use in trying to provide a brief synopsis for this ravishing tale of a young boy from India left adrift in the Pacific in a lifeboat with a tiger who used to reside in his father's zoo in Pondicherry. There is no use because once you finish the book you might decide that this was not, indeed, what the book was about at all. There is no use because, depending on your philosophical bent, the book will mean something very different to your best friend than it will to you. There is no use because it is nearly impossible to describe what makes this book so grand.<br />Read this book. Not because it is an exceptional piece of literary talent. It is, of course. But there are many good authors and many good books. While uncommon, they are not endangered. Read this book because in recent memory - aside from Jose Saramago's arresting Blindness ' there have been no stories which make such grand statements with such few elements. As Pi says in his story 'Life on a lifeboat isn't much of a life. It is like an end game in chess, a game with few pieces. The elements couldn't be more simple, nor the stakes higher.' It is the same with Martel's undulating fable of a book about a boy in a boat with a tiger. A simple story with potentially life altering consequences for it's readers.<br /> As Martel writes, \\"The world isn't just the way it is. It is how we understand it, no? And in understanding something, we bring something to it, no?\\" Like Schroedinger's cat in the box, the way this book is understood, the way it is perceived, affects what it is. There has been some talk that this book will make it's readers believe in god. I think it's a question of perspective. To behold this gem of a novel as an adventure of man against the elements (the 'dry, yeastless factuality' of what actually happened) is certainly one way to go about it. But to understand this piece to be something indescribable, something godlike, is by far the greater leap of faith.<br />Oh, but worth the leap, if the reader is like that atheist ... willing to see the better story.

B000035P7X|5.0|Dylan is chauffered back and forth, wades through rooms of strangers, waits around a lot. Hardly anything seems like much fun for him, but nearly all of it is interesting for the viewer. To relieve the boredom, Dylan lays into a herd of sacrificial lambs, slyly toying with some, nearly coming to blows with others. In most cases, he's doing these people a favor. (The film is bursting with confrontations. Just check Albert Grossman's crash course in \\"how to deal with hotel managers.\\") As the tour progresses, you can see him tiring, and by the time he delivers his unprovoked lecture to the 'Time' reporter, Dylan's all over the damn map. There's a glimmer of the self-righteousness that would sour his later years. <br />For the most part, however, Pennebaker's film catches Dylan at his most winning. His charisma is abundant; his intelligence and his fearlessness feed each other. Like Dylan's own music from this era, this portrait is quick, unsentimental, surprising.

B000000W6X|3.0|When you release one of the most influential and unique releases of the past 20 years, what do you do for an encore?  This is the no-win situation that Massive Attack had to face with their follow-up to 1991's seminal Blue Lines debut.  Whereas that album simultaneously combined smoky hip-hop, inspired soul, and laces of &quot;rasta&quot;, this album eschews many of those hip-hop and reggae elements in favour of soft jazz ('Weather Storm', 'Better Things', 'Heat Miser') and electronic-pop (such as the title track and 'Spying Glass').  Soundwise, it's a slightly uneasy mid-point between the raw urban flavour of Blue Lines and the unsettling bleakness of Mezzanine.  Overall, Protection is another high-quality release, but it falls well short of these two benchmark albums.  Musically and creatively, it is solid as expected (with the exception of their grating cover of 'Light My Fire' - but I didn't like the original either so there you go). However the combined danger and sensuality that marks Blue Lines and Mezzanine is conspicuously absent on Protection.  Even Nicolette's raspy voice on 'Three' and 'Sly' rings somehow hollow.  The album also fails to set a consistent groove: of the 10 songs, there are 2 jazzy instrumentals (both of them superb), 2 poppier tunes sung by Tracey Thorn, 2 eclectic cuts rapped by 3D and Tricky, 2 loungy rhythm-based grooves by Nicolette and 2 disappointingly un-reggae tracks by Horace Andy.  This grab bag of vocalists and styles overall simulates the disjointed feel of a compilation disc.  It not only lacks the cohesive flow of Blue Lines and Mezzanine, but is a bit bumpy in terms of quality as well.  The cuts by 3D/Tricky, Tracey Thorn and the instrumentals are absolutely ace, while Horace Andy's usually amazing voice grates on both 'Spying Glass' and 'Light My Fire'.  Nicolette's tracks are kind of in the middle, highly listenable but not the CD's bread and butter.  Overall this is not the Massive's strongest release, but mediocre Massive Attack is better than 90% of other bands at the top of their game.  It's a very good album that, however unfair it may be, is forced into comparison with their near-untouchable debut.  If taken on its own merits, Protection will not disappoint.

B00005NC66|5.0|I first watched \\"Breathless\\" in a film class my Senior year in college and I was amazed by it. Although this film was made many years ago, I was blown away by the production techniques used. Some people in my film class thought the movie was stupid and made no sense, while others (including myself) found the beauty in it's ability not to stick to the norm and be compelling in a subtle way. In a time when continuity is extremely important in film, it was refreshing to see jump cuts that were made on purpose (or rather necessity since Godard had to cut the film down considerably from his original cut). Jean-Luc Godard is a true genius!<br />This film revolves around the character of Michel, a common hood, who gets mixed up in the murder of a police officer while trying to win over the heart of the woman he loves. The plot to the story is simple, but the outcome is exciting.<br />\\"Breathless\\" is definitely not for everyone. It makes you think about hidden messages, symbolism, etc. However, it is very enjoyable and entertaining. I would highly suggest this film. I think everyone should be exposed to a Jean-Luc Godard film at least once in his or her life! This is an excellent movie!

Not perfect in the least but for what it was, very impressive.<br />Although, the music seems to fall asleep at times and Norah's playing needs more energy, it's satin-y seduction music. Not torchy, just right and mellow. One or two detractors would complain back before &quot;Come Away&quot;'s sleeper mainstream success came underway but ever since the album hit #1, hit 10 million, won up a storm at the annual Grammys, and made Norah a pop starlet, haters are coming in right and left. That's terrible if you're just saying you don't like media because of it's success. It makes sense if the music isn't for you or if you dislike it, that's called human taste BUT just bad-mouthing it because you're upset with it's level of success is called jealousy. Don't get it confused. <br />&quot;Come Away&quot; doesn't promise to be a classic or Nina Simone(RIP)/ Ella level vocal music. Not at all. It's the first entry to a exquisitely talented young lady's career. Very flawed like most debuts are but in the age of Avril Lavigne and 50 Cent, the fact that mellow loungey pop/jazz-blues hits #1 is a revelation in the world of chart-pop. Stop hating on the child's success and congratulate. (3.7 stars)
