B00008S2VG|2.0|Madonna's always been a good manipulator. Toying with one artificially intriguing public image after the next, exposing her dirty laundry gleefully in public, and manipulating the public time and time again. Madonna's one of the top five businesswomen in the music industry. But while having a great stock in business is definitely admired, what about musically? Since this IS music, isn't it? Well, Madonna, a '80s megastar on par with Michael Jackson, Prince, and Bruce Springsteen has always been an afterthought musically. Celebrity boyfriends(and, eh, girlfriends), interesting music videos and well-done publicity stunts have always superceded her musical contributions. Yeah, \\"Like A Virgin\\", \\"Holiday\\" or the retrospectively tarty \\"Vogue\\" are memorable frothy dance-pop but timeless pieces of music, they aren't. While MJ, Prince, and Springsteen have at least three classic albums to their credits, Madonna doesn't. She just doesn't. So, this leads one to question if Madonna in a way is like a Zsa Zsa Gabor type. Famous for notoriety and what she WAS.<br />\\"American Life\\", her first new release since 2000's \\"Music\\", gives some leeway into the aforementioned idea. The album's theme is fame. Questioning fame, wondering if fame made you the same person. But since Madonna's a grade A manipulator, one wonders if this is truly from the gut or just an attempt from an egotistical superstar who looking for ways to stay relevant. The title track and leadoff single, just isn't too enjoyable. A stiff techno-lite opens with strumming guitars on the chorus. The lyrics are empty and Madonna's slightly altered vocals don't elevate anything. For a mainstream pop artist, the song isn't catchy or danceable so you wonder if it'll do well on the radio. A miss. \\"Hollywood\\" and many of the proceeding tracks are very similar. Too the point where they sound like one big, long song. The electronica sound and sticky guitar-based pop melodies mix like oil and milk this time around. None are memorable and sound very conceited. From the mind of an attention-craving person who thinks her problems merit more than others. Like her '80s counterpart, Michael Jackson, Madonna takes herself way too seriously. She thinks she's her own religion. Whether if this is due to the media's persistence of treating her like some musical revolution or her own super-high level of fame, it doesn't measure up. Whereas Michael can claim decades worth of imitators. Madonna can claim who? Britney Spears? Pink? She revolutionized female images of sex and gloss, not music and presentation like Mike did. Therefore his severely big ego is a bit more justified. <br />Anyway, back on the topic of \\"American Life\\", there are some good moments. \\"Nothing Fails\\" features a London choir and a Gospel feel for extra depth. Although the song isn't powerful, it's sense of wanting is very impressive. \\"Die Another Day\\", originally featured as the Bond theme in the movie of the same name late last year, isn't too memorable but a good listen in the Madonna tradition. <br />Ultimately, \\"American Life\\" is a mediocre release from a past megastar who's simply isn't as powerful or interesting as she once was. I, personally, recommend, downloading this release, or simply going for something a tad more substantial. No disrespect to her legions of dedicated fans but this album just is rather limp, boring, and self-absorbed. American life, it's not
B00007BK2N|3.0|The history of Factory Records and Hacienda in Manchester, UK, told through the life of TV Personality and music afficianado Tony Wilson from 1976-94. B00005JLRT|3.0|The problem with a franchise like Star Trek is that it has a very committed and opinionated fan base, and so these fans will tend to be overly-critical and aggressive about their feelings regarding anything new in the franchise. Star Trek has the benefit of being based in a very broad and immersive universe that is made up of a dynamic and diverse cast of characters. This is both a blessing and a curse: a blessing because in each new motion picture installment there is a lot to build from; a curse because it can be difficult to stay true to the characters and the spirit behind the universe.<br />When making a film from the Next Generation television series, one would be confronted with two problems: the first being that the series was at times uneven and muddled; the second being that there is a different expectation in a film than in a television show. That being said, it is the characters that made the series great, and the thing that made First Contact (Trek film #8) such a resounding success is that even though it had action, it was primarily character-based and the plot had all the things that make Trek fans salivate: time travel, tough decisions and a great villain(s). I mean, really, does it get better than the Borg?<br />My girlfriend (who is a die-hard fan) and I went to see this with high hopes, and left with mixed feelings. Overall, it was a pretty decent film. It was well-paced and the action was decent. The starship battle at the end was as good as the one in Wrath of Kahn (the best of the Trek films), and the special effects were top notch. Plus, to her delight, we got to see Riker and Troi get married.<br />However, there were some acute problems, the most glaring being the overuse of Captain Picard. The director, Stuart Baird, does not treat this like the ensemble cast-driven film that it should be. Furthermore, the carefree and loose attitude that Picard seems to have developed (a dune-buggy?) is not consistent with the character that the fans grew to know and love over the television series' seven years on the air. This isn't helped by the fact that his storyline feels contrived. The motivation that the Romulans have for building a Picard-clone (his \\"nemesis\\" in the film) is flimsy and almost laughable (kind of like America's own Missile Defense Shield). Furthermore, I felt cheated by the back-story of the planet Remus (they must really dig on Roman mythology).<br />Data's storyline is old-hat, and is merely a satellite to Picard's - and everyone else is just a peripheral. I found myself wishing that Picard would just die, just so we could see some more of the other characters. The wedding scene was ok, but too short. The romantic relationship that Troi and Warf began to develop in the series goes unmentioned (again!), and a chance for some great dramatic tension between him and Riker was completely missed.<br />Nitpicking aside however, it was a decent film and clearly better than the pile of you-know-what that was Star Trek V (as one reviewer asserted) or than its muddled predecessor, Insurrection. It was entertaining, and the plot holes, even if annoying, were forgivable. The drama on Romulus was interesting, and Shinzon's ship (can't remember the name) was threatening and scary. Despite my complaints about Picard, Patrick Stewart is still a great actor and the tension that develops between him and Shinzon is engrossing (could you kill a clone of yourself?). There are some great philosophical quandaries that are raised, even if they aren't explored much, and it was suspenseful. It was Trek film that was made with its eye on the passing fan and the general public rather than the die-hard fan - which brings me back to the point that I raised earlier about the expectations for making a film being different than for a television series. In order for a studio to green-light a big-budget film like this one, it has to have broad appeal. If the film were to depend too much on obscure references and be ensemble-cast centered, it would not be nearly as appealing to Johnny Public - even if it would make a better film.<br />What I would ask for is a longer cut: I would watch 2  hours of this film if it meant that I could see more of everyone else (not another dune-buggy chase). The rumored deleted scenes sound as if they would make a killer director's cut. In future Trek films I would ask for more Brent Spiner (he is a great actor, probably the best in the bunch), for Geordi to get his cool visor back, for Picard to be treated like the Captain of a crew rather than an action star, and lastly, for a plot that involves more of the rich Trek universe, thank you.ast centered, it would not be nearly as appealing to Johnny Public - even if it would make a better film.<br />What I would ask for is a longer cut: I would watch 2  hours of this film if it meant that I could see more of everyone else (not another dune-buggy chase). The rumored deleted scenes sound as if they would make a killer director's cut. In future Trek films I would ask for more Brent Spiner (he is a great actor, probably the best in the bunch), for Geordi to get his cool visor back, for Picard to be treated like the Captain of a crew rather than an action star, and lastly, for a plot that involves more of the rich Trek universe, thank you.

0385507755|5.0|I truly enjoyed this book.  Frey's a man at home with brutality, which makes his compassion extraordinarily compelling.  The book is filled with characters whose circumstances (addiction) force them to come to terms with themselves and their lives.  What their recovery program, which binds them together, would have them come to terms with, however, is their ADDICTION.  To do this, they, Frey included, are offered 12 steps to which they're expected, even commanded, to adhere--lest they die (literally).  <br />Frey tells these character's stories with the same honesty, clarity, and immediacy that he tells his own.  Yet, he sets himself apart by steadfastly refusing to give himself over to the program, and, most pointedly, by declining to place responsibility for himself, his life and actions, over to a higher power.  <br />Frey chooses instead to take ultimate responsibility for himself and his relation to the world.  It's his choosing of this other course that makes Frey's story applicable to us all. His life story (up to age 23) is more dramatic than most, but the core issue he's chosen to address is universal:  How does one face oneself, others, and the world truthfully and without fear?       <br />A Million Little Pieces is a highly entertaining read, written in a style that marries the edge of Henry Miller with the poetry of Jack Kerouac, that serves as reflection, guide, and inspiration.  I hope it receives the status and readership it deserves.  Keep it up, Mr. Frey.  I can't wait for the next book.
B00008S2VH|4.0|Is American Life a breakthrough for madonna...or for music itself? -not really. it is rather an extension of her last album MUSIC, with more arpeggiated guitar, chirpy sometimes pastel mirwais beats & effects, and it seems with every album madonna gets more introspective & personal. The album is instantly recognizable as madonna music; the classic hooks in the songwriting are all there. Warm vocals & vocal layering dominate as in much of her more current albums. But almost gone is the sense of street life in her music...the grit of her teenage years, and the use of her upper register in her singing voice. Perhaps only in \\"I'm So Stupid\\" does she re-explore that territory. Beautiful harmonies and textures abound, but if you're looking for that 'shock & awe' dimension in other madonna material you won't find it here. Madonna has evolved-and she's honest about it. Luckily she still has that sense of adventure: madonna rap anyone? -Like it or not, madonna always gets her kudos as a risk-taker. American Life succeeds in capturing the present;The juxtaposition and melding of technology and human expression(example: signature & extreme use of vocorders). Long live madonna! Everyone will have favorites, but-Standout tracks:Hollywood,Stupid,Intervention,Nothing fails,Die Another Day(if none of us heard it before!), Mother&Father.

0783226063|5.0|When I initially saw Lynch's version of Dune, I was very impressed. The story of Paul fulfilling his destiny inspired me. This also made great use of voiceovers, which correlate to the book very well. I didn't read the book till many years later, and while Lynch's version perhaps captures the spirit of Dune in many ways, it lacks in some key areas. Harrison's version also had its flaws, but I think it addressed these things better:<br />1. Stillsuits - When I saw Harrison's version, I was disappointed in their stillsuits, because in Lynch's version, the stillsuits look awesome. However, Harrison's stillsuits make much more sense. First of all, Lynch's stillsuits are dark black, which means they would absorb more heat, which means they would likely use up more of a person's water. Second, Fremen are an evasive, secretive people. It would be a lot easier to hide in Harrison's tan stillsuits than Lynch's black stillsuits. Third, Lynch's stillsuits look almost too professional, while Harrison's look more like they were simply made.<br />2. Weirding Way - The weirding way that was so central to Lynch's battles was not in the spirit of the book. Harrison's Dune portrayed the weirding way like it was, controlling one's body and judging an opponent.<br />3. Paul and the Fremen - Kyle MacLachlan had a stronger presence than Alec Newman, and yes, Newman's character whined a lot at the beginning. MacLachlan's Paul had no real coming of age though, and didn't seem to really wrestle with doubt. Newman's Paul didn't have all the answers and was unsure of himself. He had to grow into his role. He wasn't automatically seen as the savior of the Fremen. It is even alluded to that he is manipulating the Fremen. In these respects, Newman's Paul was truer to the book.<br />All in all, I think Lynch's Dune is a better overall motion picture, but compared to the book, the journey is too perfect. Harrison's Dune is darker and more complicated, and in that respect, it captures the book muchbetter.

B00004U8DV|1.0|This album is so bad, it's almost worth owning. Track after plodding track astonishes. When I listen to this album, I feel intensely sorry for the other members of The Doors. An obviously inebriated Jimbo sounds like he couldn't decide whether to throw up or to go to sleep, so instead he went to the studio and cut some tracks. His vocals are shockingly [bad] and painfully off-key. He actually SOUNDS fat! Seriously...check it out! To make matters worse, at least half of the tunes sound like Morrison made up the abysmal lyrics as he went along. There are a couple tunes where apparently the other Doors managed to get their fearless leader semi-sobered up or at least convinced him to come up with some [bad]lyrics in advance (Riders on the Storm being the best of these), but they are the exception. Mostly the tunes are lazy, generic blues variations that a below-average bar band would be ashamed to call their own. And Morrison turns in the least convincing \\"blues\\" vocals this side of Eric Clapton's From The Cradle (yikes!)! This is bad, bad stuff. That said, it's pretty [] funny if you have a perverse enough sense of humor, and it's a great party album if your friends have a similar sense of humor. I guess nothing's all bad.
B00008PW3Q|5.0|I'm not sure I can string together mere words that will effectively communicate how much I love Fleetwood Mac's new CD Say You Will.  <br />I've been a fan from the very beginning...actually from the Buckingham Nicks time period.  I remember way back then trying to convince friends to buy the Buckingham Nicks album because I thought I had discovered something truly amazing.  And now nearly 30 years later, here I go again...telling everyone they have to run out to buy Say You Will.<br />While Christine McVie has retired to England, the essense of FM is so very much alive and kicking hard.  Say You Will is as good as Rumours, if not better because of its social commentary content.  To say this CD rocks would be an understatement.  While  Rumours was based on the open wounds of Fleetwood Mac's interpersonal relationships gone bad, Say You Will is just as raw and personal, though this time around FM is not the source of inspiration.  <br />Stevie is still the center of attention as far as I'm concerned.  I feel the true standout on this entire CD is EVERYBODY FINDS OUT.  This song rocks.  The emotion with which Stevie sings this songs conveys everything.  There is an urgency and some desperation to this song.  The use of horns and strings shows maturity and refinement that is something a bit different for FM.  <br />Another Stevie standout is GOODBYE BABY.  I've read a few music publication reviews of this song and I wonder why the \\"professionals\\" seem to miss the obvious.  As another review here mentioned, this song seems to be a lullaby song to an aborted baby...while most people see this as a song about a romantic breakup.  Stevie's voice has never ever been better.<br />WHAT'S THE WORLD COMING TO, ED MURROW TURNING OVER IN HIS GRAVE and PEACEKEEPER are awesome anthems for the times we live in. Gee, from the first drum beat of WHAT'S THE WORLD COMING TO,  I could tell the Mac was definitely back.  While some disagree with anti-war sentiment, PEACEKEEPER really touched my heart and is so thought provoking.  I realize few people know or remember Ed Murrow, but I have to agree with Lindsey...I'm sure he's turning over in his grave.  Ed Murrow was a true pioneering reporter.  News today is nothing more than a TV program used to attract viewers...Ed is turning over in his grave!<br />Stevie's first two songs...ILLUME and THROWN DOWN are shining examples of Stevie's song crafting abilities.  ILLUME tells Stevie's story about being stuck in NYC during the events of 9/11.  I know those events all too well since Stevie cancelled her concert in my hometown because she was stuck in NY.  While THROWN DOWN is yet another take on love.  I'm in awe of anyone who can write a song with the word \\"barricade\\" in it and have it come out as a hit!<br />MIRANDA and RED ROVER are typically experiement Lindsey.  RED ROVER seems to have political content with mentions of red, white and blue...<br />SAY YOU WILL is the most \\"Christine\\"-like song on this CD.  <br />The music of DESTINY RULES recalls WORLD TURNING.  <br />SMILE AT YOU is an awesome old song that fans have been dying for since hearing it in the bootlegs that are available.  <br />Something is evident.  Lindsey may very well be the perfect producer for Stevie.  I compare and contrast IT'S ONLY LOVE from Trouble in Shangri La to GOODBYE BABY...Sheryl Crow's production of IT'S ONLY LOVE results in a moody and drab sound, while Lindsey's production of GOODBYE BABY is so much better.  <br />Say You Will proves two things...Lindsey is brilliant beyond the recognition he has received and Stevie is still the reigning Queen of singer/songwriters.  <br />As awesome as Rumours is/was, Rumours has already lived through its first run and its second coming via The Dance.  Say You Will is fresh and modern.  It takes chances but doesn't alienate like Tusk did.  Lindsey uses a \\"voice in a tunnel affect\\" in several songs...EVERYBODY FINDS OUT starts off this way.  Whatever it is, I like it!  It's weird, it'sdifferent, but it's interesting in a way only Lindsey could offer.  <br />In summary...it's been one week since the release of Say You Will.  It's the only CD I have listened to since I purchased it one week ago.  I listen to it while driving to and from work...I put my headphones on each night and listen to it straigh through.  There is so much substance here...repeated listenings are necessary to take in all of awesome talent that is present.

B000001ESJ|5.0|A Farewell To The Kings(1977). Rush's 5th studio album. <br />Coming fresh off of the major underground success of the album 2112(1976), Rush follows up nicely with perhaps their greatest album of the 70s. The band were certainly rocking harder than ever, with Alex full-decked on the heavy electric guitars, along with Neil's dexteritous drum playing, and Geddy's thumping bass being stronger than ever before. Synthesizer pedals were brought forth into the music for the first time, and adds a nice backdrop touch to perfect the impact of their songs. AFTTK has something for all fans of Rush: two commercially successful short songs, two long epics, and two short undiscovered gems. <br />As for the main theme to this album, half of the songs have to do with some kind of quest or search for a certain paradise or mystery of some kind. The other half are about the effects of human nature in a society. I know that many people can interpret what each song means far better than I can, but I will provide a brief explanation of the tracks, so please bear with me. Here's the breakdown track-by-track: <br />1) A Farewell To The Kings- Excellent rocker. This song is about the struggle between people of a society and it's powerful tyrannical minority. It starts out and ends with acoustic guitar parts, but in between them is a hard rocking section with excellent riffs and strong-delivering vocals. This song actually received a bit of radio play. 9/10 <br />2) Xanadu- A phenomenal 11-minute epic, which is about the quest to find Xanadu, the land of paradise and everlasting life. However, when paradise is obtained, the adventurer remains there for 1000 years and realizes that his paradise is really full of loneliness and despair. The synth at the beginning creates a nice ambience before Alex cuts in with the guitars. It alternates between several fast and slow parts. 10/10 <br />3) Closer To The Heart- The BIG RADIO HIT, and one of the greatest fan-favorite Rush songs to date. The songis about people expressing themselves in their own ways, in order to bring themselves \\"closer to the heart\\". Brief, yet still outstanding. 10/10 <br />4) Cinderella Man- A semi-acoustic guitar-driven rocker. This song is the story of a rich man who is just trying to be friendly, is ended up being branded \\"insane\\" by the poor majority. He tries to help them, but the more he does the worse it gets. Not very long, but a good song overall. 9/10 <br />5) Madrigal- An acoustic-ballad type song about love triumphing over all of the hardships and distractions of life. This song has a good melody to it, but it's WAY TOO SHORT. Not bad by any means, but its brevity makes it seem like a wasted opportunity. 7/10 <br />6) Cygnus X-1- The other sci-fi epic of the album, and part one of a two part mega-epic. It's about the journey of an astronaut through space into the black hole of the constellation Cygnus, in order to find out what lurks beyond. Starts off with a digitized speech and droning synth effects and then explodes into a versatile rocker. Arguably the strongest track on the whole album and maybe the best of the long epics, as each part flows together nicely. Not just the lyrics, but the instrumentation playing perfectly describes each part of the journey through space, making this one hell of a rollercoaster ride of guitar, bass, and drums. Geddy's vocals are also let loose with the intense passion. Kudos guys. Kudos. 10/10 <br />Overall, I consider this album to be Rush's zenith of the progressive 70s era. Even though the followup Hemispheres(1978) is their most progressive effort, Farewell contains a stronger set of tracks that can appeal to all sorts of Rush fans. Five stars for musicianship, production, and songwriting. If you're first getting into Rush, Moving Pictures(1981), or Permanent Waves(1980) may be the best place to start, but if looked at closely, AFTTK is definitely a rocking suitable alternate. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED. PICK THIS UP NOW.

B00008S2VG|5.0|Madonna's new album &quot;American Life&quot; showcases many different musical styles. B00008BXJF|5.0|While just existing is already an astonishing feat in itself, the fact that King Crimson, the most interesting of all the original Prog. Rock innovators, is arguably at the top of their game in 2003 is mind blowing.  Few bands can reissue an expansive CD catalogue of 30th anniversary special editions and even fewer can then still claim to be writing original music, but the industrious King Crimson meets both these conditions, immediately certifying them as one of rock's most determined and persevering acts.  The group's new album, the anxiously anticipated \\"The Power to Believe,\\" acts as a companion CD to 2000's glorious landmark release, \\"The Construkction of Light.\\"  The Construkction of Light was a phenomenal display of Crimson's technological prowess, advanced instrumental abilities, and complete mastery of rock and free jazz alike, but while TCOL showed the more free jazz, unrestrained experimental side of the talented Crim, The Power to Believe is its much more straightforward rock counterpart.  Although a band as detail oriented and creative as King Crimson would never release a truly classifiable \\"rock record, \\"The Power to Believe is essentially a Crimson take on what the genre has to offer.  Packed with dense instrumentals and catchy vocal tracks alike, Crimson's new CD still keeps the group's spirit of experimentation alive, but the album's more rock driven agenda can still be easily identified.  Trading in Mastelloto's V-drums for an almost entirely acoustic set and opting for tight, spiraling riffs (Level 5, Dangerous Curves) instead of repeated, complex guitar runs (Frakctured), The Power to Believe strikes the listener in a very immediate way.  That is not to say that The Power to Believe is mundane hard rock however, far from it.  The band's superb instrumental talent as well as Belew's brilliant knack for lyrical wordplay keep the album as intelligently adventurous as it is powerful, even allowing for ambient transitions that provide a claming breakin the distorted onslaught.  Even more astonishing though, under the hard rock veneer lies the typical Crimson complexity; entirely intact and bubbling just below the surface to reward the focused listener.  In this way, the band remains as brilliantly original as ever through irregular solos and alternating guitar blasts, but the far more accessible rock packaging which contains the group's Avant Garde tendencies adds focus and drive to King Crimson's already formidable sound.  The Power to Believe is therefore at its heart another classic, otherworldly King Crimson album, as shocking and successful as releases from In The Court of the Crimson King up to The Construkction of Light, but in addition to flexing King Crimson's established fortes, The Power to Believe pushed their sound forward into the future, conquering the worlds of Prog., hard rock, alt., metal, jazz, and countless other styles in its wake.

B00008S2VG|3.0|After listening to this CD multiple times, I still have not developed the addictive feeling that every other Madonna album has instilled in me. Then there's the shelved, \\"what-was-she-thinking?\\" video for the title song, which it so direly needed to push it up the charts. But wait! There is the rest of the music itself. No longer five steps ahead of everyone else in the music biz, her never-ending Mirwais obsession has become a droning bore. Every song sounds vaguely like the one before it, and the one before that, and the one before that...<br />The lyrics are standard grammar-school rhyming. Okay, maybe her lyrics were always simple, but here there's no help from the surrounding production, or her singing, which is now totally bereft of any phrasing. Her vocals are bogged down and interrupted with a trillion bleeps, cut-offs, re-verbs, overdubs, and alterations.<br />But what really gets me is the whole emotional timbre of this set of songs. It's downright morose. The poor girl doesn't seen happy or content with anything in her life. She should come to work with me for a couple of days, then she'd really have some down-beat ideas to peddle. Madonna, honey, we never listened to you because we wanted to feel depressed and conflicted.<br />I hope this current Madonna incarnation comes to a halt, pronto.  I loved all her other personas and music styles: fun-loving tramp, material girl, spiritual traveller, cowgirl. But this \\"queen-of-doom\\" personality ran out of steam before she could finish changing her hair color.<br />I would have given \\"A.L.\\" two stars, but there are some listenable tracks. Listenable, but not by any means the greatness we've come to expect. Sigh... What a letdown. I hope she gets some objective consultants to keep this from ever happening again. 038572179X|5.0|The plots of some books are easily categorized.  Ones where the first paragraph lets you know what the arc of the book is going to be.  It sounds interesting.  You want to read it.  You were right in your prediction.  It gives you a comfortable feeling to have been right.  And you don't have to think.  This is not one of those books.  At least in its most fundamental sense it is not.<br />It seems to be at first.  In 1935, on a country estate, a young girl with a vivid imagination tries to explain something that she sees.  She does not understand what she has seen, but how many of us do at that age.  She thinks she has seen something she has not.  She is not puzzled, she is sure of what she has seen, and what it means, but she is wrong.  That evening other events lead to misleading, but convincing, statements to the police.  Then everyone must live with the consequences.  Five years later, that now young woman must come to grips with what she has set in motion, and its consequences.<br />Simple enough, and if that was all there was, it would be a good book.  That's not all there is.  The book goes further forward, to 1999.  Events have played out.  People have lived their lives.  We have to accept truth, and the truth is what makes what would be a good book a great book.<br />The difference, the ending, makes it a fantastic choice for those of us who hate to read a book only once!
0553381709|5.0|I can accept that some people will not like A Song Of Ice And Fire, after all this is a matter of personal taste, but what has confused me somewhat are reviews from those who profess to have loved the first two books in the series and yet find A Storm Of Swords a disapointment. Some has critized the lack of resolution in the book to which I can only point to the fact that, while certain subplots are resolved, three more books have yet to come in which there will be plenty of space for resolution.  Others have marked the book down because of the affect certain scenes had on them, I would argue that it is a testament to the quality of the book that it can evoke such a powerful responce in the reader.<br />In the end I can only offer my opinion for what it's worth that this is one of the most remarkable series around at the moment.  If your tired of the usual conventions of the genre it's a breath of fresh air and I cannnot recomend it highly enough

B00008S2VG|5.0|For 20 years, the sounds and images of modern pop's most resilient icon has kept audiences mesmerized.  Acclaimed and derided for her keen marketing sense, Madonna's music always seemed to take the backseat to her public image.  Whatever your thoughts may be on Ms. Ciccone, she is a part of popular history for a reason.  She's a damn exciting artist and performer.  With \\"American Life,\\" her new age of maturity and introspection reveals the true depths of her ability as a musician -- at long last.<br />While \\"Ray of Light\\" has been hailed as her artistic high point, \\"American Life\\" scales a taller peak.  Musically, this is not for the bump and grind of the dance floor, long her strongest suit.  This time, Madonna has offered personal attacks, views, revelations and other inner monologues -- all produced in a fractured soundscape that is a complex as the album's themes.  With the jarring debut single and her scathing attack on \\"Hollywood,\\" the Material Girl questions her own decisions for the first time.  The beauty of music like \\"Love Profusion\\" and \\"Easy Ride\\" are both revealing and shocking since it came from the same mind that was the source of songs like \\"Vogue\\" and \\"Lucky Star.\\"<br />Looking back at the two decades she has cornered the air waves, it is remarkable to chart her evolution.  Most of top 40's reigning and now deposed royalty of pop are nowhere to be seen.  Today's current idols don't even write their own music, much less strum a guitar.  Madonna has accomplished a rare feat, remaning a vibrant part of the art form by leading, not following its fickle trends.<br />Since cynicism seems to be a professional sport of late, it is not fair to count her out.  That is why art remains the ultimate in subjective thought.  Give it a chance. \\"American Life\\" is not going to set your toes tapping on the onset.  You may even find yourself grumbling about purchasing it in the first place. But this is some special music and it deserves repeated listenings.  I know I grew up with Madonna and it is thrilling to have her provide a different kind of soundtrack to this adult's life. A recommendation to all without reservations.I grew up with Madonna and it is thrilling to have her provide a different kind of soundtrack to this adult's life. A recommendation to all without reservations.

Though his love for sci-fi was quite evident in his first movie, \\"THX-1138\\", where did he get 1) The filmmaking acumen, 2) the money, 3) the technically adept people to pull \\"New Hope\\" off? Clarke and Douglas Trumbull to make \\"2001\\".<br /><br />\\"New Hope\\" had that magic touch that had you rooting for the heroes at every turn, predisposing you to this by painting the Empire as the very embodiment of evil....destroying Luke's home and BURNING Beru and Owen, blowing up Leia's homeworld and killing Obi Wan. Carries Fisher's whole face goes from being round and pudgy to being elongated and gaunt, though she still pretty much resembles the \\"New Hope\\" Leia. Her voice, however, changes completely, going from tomboyish but still feminine in \\"New Hope\\", to being raspy and whiskey-soaked by \\"Jedi\\".<br /><br />All in all, this is the one that sets the pace for the others, and is STILL the best one as far as pathos and pure edge-of-your-seat drama: The destruction of Luke's farm and the murder of his guardian Aunt and Uncle; the destruction of Alderaan by Grand Muff Tarkin; the trash-compactor scene; the rebel pilots being picked off one by one by the Empire fighters during the Death Star run by Luke's friends. The last minute save by Han Solo...this film couldn't have been a more perfect matinee entertainment if it tried!<br /><br />Special mention has to be made of Sir Alec Guiness and Peter Cushing, especially Cushing, who gave perhaps his best film performance ever in this film as the supremely evil Tarkin. The sad thing connected with this film is the lackluster career Mark Hamill has had since \\"Jedi\\". Since then I've been a huge Nicks fan and in an effort to find more of her music I discovered Fleetwood Mac.  I've been a fan ever since I first heard 'The Dance'.  That being said, realize this reveiw is coming from the perspective of someone who is a Nicks fan first and a Fleetwood Mac fan second.<br />The first reason I love this album is because Nicks has some great songs on here.  Everybody Finds Out is a great rock song and gets me psyched up no matter how many times I've heard it before.  Say You Will is a nice pop song, but I actually think it would have been better sung by Christine McVie.  Nicks does a nice job filling in for her though.  Illume is a prime example of just how wonderfully cryptic and beautiful Nicks' poetic songs can be.  Finally, Running Through the Garden harkens back to some of Nicks' solo work from the 80's, especially from 'The Wild Heart'.  <br />Lindsey Buckingham has some good moments on this album as well, but some of his songs seem to be out of place here.  'Red Rover' and 'Murrow Turning Over In His Grave' are good examples of songs that would have been better on a Buckingham solo project.  However, since 'Say You Will' came out of such a project, that doesn't come as a surprise.  'Peacekeeper', however, is a great example that Fleetwood Mac hasn't lost its distinctive sound.<br />Probably the best part about this album though are the pair of songs at the end.  'Say Goodbye' (sung by Buckingham) and 'Goodbye Baby' (sung by Nicks) are essentially Nicks and Buckingham putting closure on their volatile relationship that spawned some of Fleetwood Mac's most famous songs.  Its a very nice way to end the album and it ends on a most satisfying note.<br />Only big Fleetwood Mac fans should by the 'Enhanced' album.  It contains some nice picture extras, and the extra songs are decent.  But casual fans may not appreciate these extras to justify the extra cost.  The serious fan will very much enjoy the Enhanced version though.
630463949X|4.0|I am a huge FM fan.  I was sceptical about buying this because the band hadn't been together for awhile, and well, they were older.  I wondered if the magic had been lost.  All I can say is that I was a fool to think that!  I could have been enjoying this concert DVD ages ago.  <br />I bought the DVD this week after reading such positive reviews on Amazon.  Stevie Nick's voice is still in top form, despite what others have said about her voice during this concert.  She also seemed to really enjoy being back on stage with the band.  It's common knowledge that Christine McVie didn't want to be part of this concert, and it shows. This is my only complaint with the concert - she rarely smiles and looks out of place - she has the look of \\"is it time to go yet?\\"  She puts only an average effort into the songs she sings at this concert.  Anyway, aside from that, you get FM showcasing some of their best stuff including brilliant renditions of \\"Tusk\\" and \\"Landslide\\".  <br />I can't recommend this music DVD enough, it's brilliant.  It might not have DTS, but that isn't a problem - the 5.1 is absolutely fine.  This is a music DVD that belongs in every FM fan's collection.  Buy it and treasure it.
0553213105|5.0|Being a 20 something male, I was not sure what to think when I picked up this novel.  I knew that girls had always loved this book, so I set myself up for a girlie novel.  Elizabeth, the protaganist, is anything but a simple girlie character though.  This book attacks the social structure of Austen's days.  The characters are deep and well written.  Some are characatures for comic relief, but you still come away with the feeling that you have known someone like that in the past.  This book is a classic for a reason.  I recommend this book to anyone, not just love sick teenage girls.

B00008S2VG|2.0|Okay, So Madonna is a star. She's sick and tired of being a star. All you need is love. Playing guitars automatically makes what you're saying really really important. On her latest super-hyped project 'American Life', Madonna desperately tries to keep her position as controversial quick-change artist, with plenty left to say on sex, politics, family, and (oh god!)the price of fame. What results is the same sob-story she gave us on 2000's 'Music' and 1998's 'Ray Of Light', only this time the experimentation with electronica and intense introspection has become just more digital whining and kumbaya sing along babble. While 'Music' was half of what 'Ray' was, it still managed to be engaging enough to be left knowing Madonna was still at the top of her game. This, her tenth album, is her weakest because there are no new tricks and the subject matter has all been covered before. The family and religious themes of \\"Mother and Father\\" and \\"Nothing Fails\\" recall 'Like A Prayer', which remains her best album to date. The choir in \\"Nothing Fails\\" makes you really miss that period. That's the problem with 'Life'.There are fragments sprinkled throughout that remind you of her past catalog and then something obnoxious happens again-another tune where either Madonna's guitar gently weeps and she talks out of her spiritual behind or a pretty good dance tune (\\"Nobody Knows Me\\", \\"Hollywood\\")is partnered with lyrics my two year old niece could write (\\"Im stupider than stupid\\"). What is really wrong with the whole thing is the concept of soul searching-something we're already well aware and tired of. The title track, maybe the strongest now that we've heard the rest of the album, tries to deliver social commentary with that same ego-bad, Kabaalah-good sermon. We get treated to Madonna's horrible habit of simple pop rhymes-bar,star,far, dream,seem (later fly, sky, cry are used to death). This is forgivable for the first five or so songs of your career...but we know Madonna is capableof making stronger songs. \\"American Life\\" would be a better Madonna song without the cringe-inducing embarrassment of that rap, where she lists those shallow things she hates so much (but it would be more believable if her whole career had never been based on self-love, brattiness, carelessness, and the ability to morph into a new piece of eye candy during her latest project) What should sound like a mature woman making relevant, envelope-pushing music sounds like a woman that couldn't even reach the level of \\"Like A Virgin\\". Madonna has sucked the life out of her art, under the illusion that her enlightenment, her motherhood, and her love of cyber-chucky space beats is still enough to stay in the groove. I think many buyers of her latest scheme may disagree with her. All this time, we've followed her simply because of the excitement that has always surrounded a hot off the press Madonna album. But for the first time, Madonna has not evolved any more since the last time. Her shock-appeal is already showing age-would the same Madonna 13 years ago not release a video because it might offend someone? No. But that is where we are at right now. I won't go as far as to say Madonna has totally lost it, but she has definitely lost focus of what has worked for her for 20 years: never doing the same thing twice. My advice to Madonna: get new producers, ditch techno, and remember this: songs don't have to rhyme! In other words, get back into the groove or get out.<br />Standouts: American Life (minus the rap), \\"Hollywood\\", \\"Nobody Knows Me\\"(the beats), \\"Nothing Fails\\"(Minus some lyrics), Mother and Father\\" (Minus some dopey lyrics),\\"Die Another Day\\"-the only flawless song.

B00007L7FN|4.0|Tangerine Dream was going through a slow period of transition from 1970's &quot;Alpha Centauri&quot; to 1974's &quot;Phaedra&quot;. This album represents a step in that transition where the band finally begins to embrace electronic instruments as their primary tools, while still holding on to some of their &quot;Alpha Centauri&quot;-type experimental approach. This is the last TD album released before they went to England to record with Virgin, and also the last studio album to feature drums until 1979's &quot;Cyclone&quot;.<br />Personally, I find this album somewhere between the industrial freakouts of &quot;Electronic Meditation&quot; and the icy moonscapes of &quot;Zeit&quot;. There are some wild and crazy moments, but the disc is dominated by a sense of space, and empty quietness. Quite a lot of the album sounds like Zeit outtakes or backing tracks waiting for a solo, but they provide a nice contrast to the louder, more upfront moments.<br />This is the first TD album to feature the Mellotron, which would become a staple of the Tangerine Sound in the following decade. The album is drenched in Mellotron, but the instrument is most prominent in the first two tracks, the sidelong epic &quot;Atem&quot; and the shorter, mysterious &quot;Fauni-Gena&quot;. &quot;Fauni-Gena&quot; also contains some kind of backing track made up of jungle bird noises.<br />Overall, I would say that if you like &quot;Alpha Centauri&quot;s first side, you'll like this record. Bear in mind that the primitive recording environment is made evident in the amount of tape hiss throughout the album, but that's easy to ignore.
0385504209|3.0|I found \\"The Da Vinci Code\\" to be an entertaining thriller based on the theories presented in \\"Holy Blood, Holy Grail\\" by Baigent, Leigh and Lincoln.<br />Brown's comments about the Louvre and Leonardo were the most interesting parts of the book for me. Having a man who studies symbols as his hero can lead to some intriguing puzzles to solve, as in \\"The DaVinci Code.\\"<br />Brown's treatment of the Catholic Church, however, is shallow and predictable. It is as if Catholics are the only Christians. (They are not even the most anti-female Christians). And although the secret society presented in the book is known to have been a hoax, as a previous reviewer stated, it makes for a nice plot device. But Brown claims that its existence is a fact.<br />There also are times when the characters do some remarkably stupid things, just to move the plot along. For that reason, I have given the book three stars.<br />If you enjoy art, ancient religions, and code breaking, this book is for you. Just don't expect great literature.

0151008116|5.0|What can you say about a book that won what's probably the most prestigious literary prize in the world (England's Booker Prize)?  Well for starters, Life of Pi doesn't read like a prize-winning novel.  It's a funny, page-turning romp that moves from the former capital of French India to modern-day Canada by way of a 26-foot lifeboat.  Marooned on the lifeboat is Pi Patel, a precocious 16 year old.  The novel begins with the story of Pi's childhood, which has no shortage of wonder.  Pi's days are spent between school, life at his family's business (the only zoo in former French India) and religious devotion (to Hinduism, Christianity, and Islam).  But the novel really takes off when the ship ferrying Pi and his family to Canada goes down, and Pi is (literally) tossed into a lifeboat that's home to a wounded zebra, a hungry hyena, a prized orang-utan, and a 450-pound Bengal tiger named Richard Parker.  The boat's population undergoes a swift decline, and soon only Pi and Richard Parker remain, stranded, with no hope of rescue.  <br />For most writers, simply coming up with such a wild premise would drain their imagination dry.  But not Martell.  Every page of Life of Pi is crammed with charm, elegance, wit and wisdom.  He never lets his reader down, even when he twists the story around in the final five chapters.<br />The book is just magnificent.  Stylistically, Martell is a born storyteller.  He combines a never-failing array of similes with strong, clean sentences, and an easy charm.  Intellectually, he enlivens the narrative with ideas and themes that kept me up at night days after I put the book down.  <br />I can't sing the praises of this book high enough.  Just heavenly.

PS-love the Patty Hearst/Che Guevara thing.<br />(Hollywood) continues with the opening theme of having it all yet having nothing of true value, futility at the alter of false gods, etc...\\"push the button, change the channel\\" done with another vocal distortion, kinda like Bowies FAME in a weird way. <br />(I'm So Stupid) \\"Living in a fuzzy dream\\" is rather stupid, isn't it?  I feel stupid too, sometimes. Maybe I'll turn the TV off now. If this kind of modern life is not for free, then what AM I paying? Trippy opening vocal bit worth the price of admission. <br />(Love Profusion) There is one solution--\\"Open Your Heart\\" <br />(Nobody Knows Me) \\"No one tells you how to live your life but its just a setup until your fed up\\" The album progresses with this track, and seems to point to killing your television (media? entertainment?) to cut the crap and social disease out of your life.  \\"People trap(ping) your mind\\". Rather subversive message. Viva la Revolucian!<br />(Nothing Fails) \\"I'm Not Religious\\".  Hmmmmm. I don't believe her. Maybe she means she isn't into belief systems.  Cause, I mean, she's just .... religious. Duh. <BR>OK use of choir--much much subltler than \\"Like A Prayer\\".<br />(Intervention) Second love song in a row. Great realization of folk/electro sound. Pretty chorus. Should be a single. Maybe 'All You Need Is Love' is the answer to our American Lives?<br />(X-Stactic Process) Letter to Jesus on personal messed up Roman-Catholic-Jesus-love stuff here. Campfire song about toxicity. Can't really relate, but from what I hear, a few of you perhaps will.  Sound is Veronica Electronica meets Joni Mitchell up in Laurel Canyon for tea. Beautiful.<br />(Mother and Father) \\"There was a time I prayed to Jesus Christ, There was a a time I had a mother it was nice\\"  We're deep in the doodoo of emotional pain as she turns her back on it. A gentle John Lennon's 'Mother' with a rap in place of the primal scream. 'Momma Don't Go, Daddy come home.' <br />(Die Another Day) Best thing she's done since Ray of Light. And as an added bonus, her most sly and subtle lyrics.  Every morning I wake up and die another day, and it makes me happy.<br />(Easy Ride) I guess no one would let Madonna get away with titling the song 'What I Want' but it is exactly that-a nice closeout song with wishes. I guess you still want things even though you have everything?  Beautiful.

B000001GPX|5.0|I was encouraged to buy this performance of the 5th by the overwhelming recommendation of reviewers at Amazon.com. And, they were right. This is a tremendous performance that far exceeds others that I own by Solti or Bohm (although I prefer Bohm on the 7th). Kleiber imparts majesty without bombast or pomposity. He actually renewed my interest in the 5th, which is so recognizable that it almost becomes cliche. He and the Vienna Philharmonic just nail this symphony, placing emphasis where it enlivens the whole performance.<br />DG did a great job recording and remastering these two performances. Although vintage 1975 and 76, these analog recordings are truly excellent in quality, comparable to digital. What a great compliment to such a stellar performance.<br />Not to detract from this CD, which I believe to be the best traditional performance of Beethoven's 5th, but let me also suggest the new interpretations of Beethoven's symphonies performed by David Zinman on Arte Nova. The performances are so different that they encourage one to appreciate each, but not to the exclusion of the other. Regardless, do not fail to obtain this performance.

B0000041DF|2.0|I purchased this CD based upon many favorable reviews on Amazon.com and by Argerichs success with the concertos of Prokofiev and Ravel.  The assumption was that if one can successfully master Prokofievs 3rd, one can play the Rach 3rd with equal aplomb.  Bad assumption.<br />Ms. Argerich plays with passion.  Unfortunately, this passion comes at the cost of articulation.  We can blame the recording engineers for some the sonic confusion (and they deserve it in these two live recordings), but the individual notes are not well defined and seemed slurred in these performances.  Its easier to forgive mistakes in playing these pieces than it is to excuse her lack of emphasis and articulation.  In her defense, she was more successful with Tchaikovsky than with Rachmaninoff. <br />On the sonic side, these recordings are an engineering nightmare.  The piano is close-miked in the Rachmaninoff concerto so at times it covers 100% of the stage.  Sometimes you can hear the treble keys coming out of the left speaker, only, while the bass is emanating from the right.  It is clear that the engineers emphasized the piano, which often overpowered the orchestra.  I should probably be flattered: this is the first time I have heard the Rach 3rd while perched on the lap of the pianist.<br />Although better in the Tchaikovsky performance, the sound engineering still hampered the performance in that piece, too.  The piano which usually appeared on the right, managed to move to middle stage more than once.  The dynamics in this recording were also mediocre at best, and not the least bit enveloping.<br />If we are supposed to excuse the limitations of live recordings, the faults should at least be unavoidable and not self-induced.  (I did not even mention the prevalent tape hiss in the quiet passages of the Rach concerto.)  In the end, the distractions from the sound engineers forces a thumbs-down on these recordings.  For the Rach concerto, consider Ashkenazy/Previn or Gutierrez/Maazel.  For Tchaikovsky, try Van Cliburn/Kondrashin, Giles/Mehta, or Watts/Levi.<br />If I did not already own prior performances by Ms. Argerich, I might have written her off forever after listening to this disaster.

B00000427L|5.0|I love Rachmaninoff, especially these piano concertos, and Ashkenazy and Previn provide us with masterful performances. You really need to compare other performances of these concertos to know just how good these are.  The beauty of these performances is that everything comes together with such refinement.  Previn exhibits a great understanding of these pieces and the LSO responds well (as usual).  Ashkenazy is precise and yet expressive at the same time.  He articulates each note so clearly.  But more than this, Previn and Ashkenazy are magically attuned to each other.  The music flows with a perfect balance between piano and orchestra.<br />These analog recordings from Decca are excellently engineered.  The dynamic range is exceptional with a wide soundstage.  As with other London/Decca and DG recordings, the midrange brass has a slight edge to it.  Also, Ashkenazy is close miked, so his piano extends across 60% of the soundstage, which is not exactly realistic.  However, these are minor quibbles that do not detract from a masterful performance and an otherwise expansive, crisp recording.<br />There is no reason to restrict oneself to a single performance of these marvelous concertos.  But, if ever I had to restore my collection, I would purchase this set first.

B000001GQQ|5.0|I purchased this CD for the Ravel concerto.  I own other performances of Prokofiev, but another interpretation is always welcome.  It doesn't really matter, because the performances of both pieces are very good.  Ms. Argerich plays deftly and the demands of these pieces, particularly the Prokofiev, do not impede her well-chosen pace.  She really knows the Prokofiev and it shows.  Additionally, she and Abbado are in sync, and the sound of the piano and orchestra are well balanced.  Under Abbado's direction, the Ravel concerto is sprite and lively.<br />The sonics of these mostly-1967 recordings are excellent.  These recordings have depth and extension.  The clarity and detail really favor the Ravel concerto.<br />There are others (Ashkenazy/Previn, Graffman/Szell, Berroff/Masur) who perform the Prokofiev well, but this coupling of Argerich/Abbado is also good. B00000IFP6|5.0|Compared to traditional interpretations, performances by Zinman strike me as being more intimate.  The Zurich ensemble sounds smaller, on a smaller stage, and gives the impression of playing to a few close friends and me.  Initially, I thought this smaller venue would benefit only the first four symphonies, but in truth all symphonies came across as fresh and lively, even the 9th.<br />We traditionally hear these symphonies with large, lush orchestras.  In contrast, these are leaner and slimmer.  Don't misunderstand, these are not lightweight, and it seems to make the orchestra more nimble.  The lessened reverberation from the concert hall is in keeping with this slimmer approach.<br />Digital recordings do not always equate to perfect sonics, but the engineers did a superb job of capturing these symphonies as clear and realistic.  You feel that you are there with the orchestra.  The tempo of most pieces is more brisk, but does not seem rushed (except the opening of the 5th which initially took me by surprise).  I envision listening to \\"traditional\\" performances sitting back in an comfortable leather chair with a glass of port.  Zinman's performances have me on the edge of my chair, anxious to catch the next nuance.  This sprite approach to well known Beethoven need not replace traditional performances, but for now, I will continue to enjoy these Zinman performances more frequently.  This cycle is easily 5 stars.
B00005A46T|5.0|First of all, I am not a 'poser', a term found in several reviews of this cd to label the people who actually appreciate this band. Slipknot was one of those bands I had heard a lot about, but never heard them play. I usually hang around with a crowd that listens to Iced Earth, Megadeth, Slayer, etc. (\\"old metal\\"). I make a regular habit of listening to these bands as well, and hold old metal in higher regards than \\"nu metal\\". So when Slipknot first came out, people said \\"They're no good, they're no good. Complete waste of time. No talent bla bla bla ...\\" And like a fool, I listened to them. I let '99 - '02 pass me by thinking this band was the definition of what a 'metal' band should not be. While all the time never hearing them, for keep in mind, Slipknot is not played on the radio. Finally in February '03 I saw a used copy of Iowa available for [cheap]. It kept catching my eye as I walked past it, with it's shiny cover with a goat on it. Finally, I figured \\"What the hell?\\" and snatched it for cheap. After the first listen to \\"People = S***\\", I knew that the whole time my \\"old metal\\" friends were actually the ones being posers. They couldn't name a single Slipknot song, or recognize any material if played for them. They, like me, had never heard Slipknot. So, here I am, a fan of \\"old metal\\" getting into a band four years later that is on the verge of breakup right now. <br />I will tell you the truth. Slipknot kicks royal [butt], and here are just a few things I love. You may be aware that Corey Taylor also sings for Stone Sour, a sing-songy melodic ... band. Well, there are no clean vocals on this album. None. Corey has even said that he has almost lost his voice just singing for the band. Corey Taylor has a unique way of fading in and out of this blood curdling vocal performance to a kind of talk-singing back into a scream again. There is also a fast delivery of words, some consider this rap, but there is just no way. The whole time Corey Taylor is delivering his voice, he is screaming. You must understand that this music is so fastpaced, that any slower of a delivery from Corey would seem out of step, making it sound awkward. I'm sorry, rappers do not rap while they are screaming their lungs out. POD raps, RATM raps, Linking Park raps, Slipknot does not. There is no normal monotonous voice talking with a rhythm to the music, ever. Fast demon-like screaming is all you are going to get. Corey's lyrics are very angry as well, which is the way it should be in metal, and I like it. You might also be aware that this band has a \\"dj\\" in it. I'm sorry about that too, for the only indication I get of a turntable in use is on \\"People = S***\\", and this scratch is not even a scratch, not to mention not even a funky-feeling hip hop vibe is detectable in the noise that the record makes, it's more of a haunting sound. Mind you, I only here a turntable used once distinctly on #2, the rest of its use and use of the samples are faint in the background in songs like \\"New Abortion\\". One thing I will admit about Slipknot is that the guitars make funny Korn-like noises sometimes, but not often enough to bother me. What we actually have here is a rather talented and decent band, the three beat keepers (two percussionists, and a drummer) work wonderfully together, and their best work can be found on \\"People = S***\\", \\"Disasterpiece\\", and \\"New Abortion\\", not only is the drummer good on double bass, but does great armwork as well, not to mention being assisted even moreso by two others playing percussion. The percussion work on Iowa is INTENSE to say the least, in fact I would say that work at percussion is the thing that Slipknot does best, not guitarwork like most metal bands like to boast. As for the guitarists themselves, they are nothing to really boast about, but they alright in keeping up with the speedy percussion work and making funny noises. (They play fast enough and talented enough to satisfy me.) Bottom line, there is pretty much nothing hip hop about Slipknot, this is dark, death screamy stuff. If you do not like death screamy stuff, then forget this, for there is no singing (except a little on \\"My Plague\\"). Slipknot is intense music that I can appreciate. And another thing, I'm 19 going on to 20, and I like this, so if this music is supposed to be meant for young kiddies around the ages of 13 and 14 (which, judging by the lyrics I would hope not), then I may possibly never grow up. This is good stuff period. Although I did find the song \\"Skin Ticket\\" a little annoying ....

Kenny in hell, Stan's quest for the clitoris. They're running gags but they hold up as plot points. Here the intensity is cranked up a few notches but in all South Park - Bigger, Longer & Uncut is very funny.<br />It would have been nice with more features or commentary tracks but hey, it's still a fun film that'll teach you and your kids new and better ways of verbally abusing one another. :)<br />Sweet!

Just like many Chinese marital artists, his work is also kind of unfinished, but that's because Chinese martial artists usualy don't think the art is &quot;speakable.&quot;  However, in contrast to many other books, this one is still very worth reading and pondering, and kind of easy.<br />The drawings themselves have helped me very much when I was studying martial arts. Chinese called him &quot;Three-leg Lee.&quot;  He told his student to feel and react but not to think about how to do it. B000059H9E|4.0|Odd little film (even for Almodovar) that deals with the consequences faced by a prostitute's son when he shoots and paralyzes a police officer during a fight with a drug dealer...who turns out to be the cop's wife! Only Pedro Almodovar could have directed this strange little tale, adapted from Ruth Rendell's equally strange novel. It starts slowly, taking an almost aloof approach to the characters and situations, but once the plot swings into action, emotions and personalities (an Almodovar specialty) take center stage, and the film's tone begins to veer wildly from comedy to drama to tragedy to irony. Such a hodgepodge of moods shouldn't mesh, and in the hands of most other directors, this would be an incoherent mess. But Almodovar makes it work with strong characters and a remarkable sense of timing, both comedic and dramatic (especially near the end). Great performances (especially by Liberto Rabal, Javier Bardem, and the stunning Francesca Neri) are also a plus, and Almodovar was wise to pepper his film with strong personalities who make the emotional content of the film more believable, and certainly more palatable, especially when the viewer is subjected to sometimes wild swings in the film's tone. On a par with Almodovar's best works, such as \\"Talk to Her\\" and \\"Woman on the Edge of a Nervous Breakdown.\\"

0226264211|4.0|\\"Capitalism and Freedom\\", the 2002 version, contains a brief preface for the 2002 edition, as well as the preface to the 1982 edition.  On the subject of whether he would revise anything to his original work, Friedman said, with one exception, that he wouldn't.  There's good reason for that.<br />The book is written for a generalist audience (like me), and pulls back from the nuts and bolts of economic theory in order to provide a broad scope that makes sense in plain English.  With broad subject matter such as \\"The Control of Money\\", \\"Fiscal Policy\\", and \\"The Role of Government in Education\\", all of which average around 20 pages each in a 200 page book, the reader will not be in danger of getting bogged down in esoteric details.<br />Some of the subject matter that Friedman speaks of in the present tense is only relevant in historical terms (such as the segment on the gold standard for monetary policy).  Other chapters speak directly to current issues (such as his chapter on the virtues of school vouchers, or the chapter on social welfare measures).  <br />Because the book was written in the pre-Civil Rights Act era and makes no apologies for the least amount of government restraint on economic relationships, the book provides an insightful glimpse of what free-market conservatives believed before the political paradigm shift.  Friedman takes the proper care to say he does not favor racial discrimination, but he also makes it clear that government intervention into such economic relationships doesn't necessarily make things better.<br />Friedman contributes a lot on the subject of monopolies, whether they be technical monopolies, private monopolies, or government monopolies, and which of them would be the least damaging under the circumstances.  In the same vein as Adam Smith's talk of the danger of private collusion, the danger of a private monopoly holding together is much less probable than a government monopoly or a technical monopoly.<br />All in all, for someone looking for a primer on conservative economics, this relatively inexpensive book is a safe bet.
B000002L7R|4.0|The 80s wouldn't have been the 80s without Prince.  Around the World in a Day was his follow-up album to the immensely popular Purple Rain.  While this album is certainly not as momentous as its predecessor, it most certainly does have its good points.  First of all, and I think this was a wise decision on Prince's part, Around the World in a Day has a different feel and sound to it than Purple Rain, a new mood which the cover of the album ably reflects.  There are psychedelic touches to this music, as well as a plethora of Indian and perhaps oriental sounds, that give the album a somewhat upbeat, rather mystical atmosphere.  The opening track Around the World in a Day sets the record straight from the very beginning, giving ample warning that this album is not going to be a Purple Rain knockoff by an artist content to coast his way down from the top of the mountain of superstardom.  Raspberry Beret was naturally a huge hit, and it has something of a light, energetic quality to it that makes it fun to listen to even now.  Pop Life is another pop-oriented song that got ample play on the radio, and its airy yet serious style is quite in contrast to the song and released single America.  America has a dose of serious guitar of a slightly heavy variety, making me think of (yet not actually reminding me of) Jimi Hendrix, except Jimi never screamed the way Prince does on this track.  Paisley Park is a wonderful song, boasting some of Prince's best and most emotionally touching lyrics.  It is followed by the equally impressive yet very different song Condition of the Heart; this love song starts with some impressive tickling of the ivories before eventually leading into Prince's high-key and perfectly mournful lyrics.  The final two tracks offer another contrast in styles.  After The Ladder, a serious, even philosophical track with something of a gospel sound to it, Prince immediately shifts gears to the wild, uninhibited, scream-heavy Temptation.  I can't say what kind of reaction die-hard Prince fans had to this album when it was released, but I admit having initially found it a little disappointing compared to Purple Rain.  Now, it is easy to look back and see how well most of this music holds up.  Prince always did his own thing yet remained highly successful, and this album is a case in point.  I could do with a few less of those vintage Prince screams, but overall I have a lot of respect for the new direction Prince followed on the heels of Purple Rain.reaction die-hard Prince fans had to this album when it was released, but I admit having initially found it a little disappointing compared to Purple Rain.  Now, it is easy to look back and see how well most of this music holds up.  Prince always did his own thing yet remained highly successful, and this album is a case in point.  I could do with a few less of those vintage Prince screams, but overall I have a lot of respect for the new direction Prince followed on the heels of Purple Rain.

B00008S2VG|2.0|Having been a fan of Madonna since 1984, I've been loyal to her through the highs and lows (personal highs being &quot;Like A Prayer&quot; and low definitely being &quot;Bedtime Stories&quot;.)    She's got a great voice, so what possesses her to rely on Auto Tune? (aka the &quot;Cher&quot; effect from &quot;Believe&quot;) It was fun to hear a little of the electronic vocal effects on the &quot;Music&quot; LP, but it's just a gadget that is going to make these records sound incredibly dated very quickly.    But as on &quot;Music&quot;, this album lazily re-treads on the chopped up acoustic guitars, piercing ultrasonic synth noises and over compressed electronic percussion.   These are all great things in the remix world, but for an album, it left me feeling empty after my initial listen.   Maybe I'm getting too old to be the target audience these days, but the artistry, wonderful vocals and harmonies and overall well crafted pop music that I've come to expect from Madonna are devoid on &quot;American Life&quot;.  Not to mention that horribly depressing cover artwork.      Don't get me wrong..  I love electronic music (I think &quot;Ray of Light&quot; was a totally brilliant album) but this album has crossed the line of pop music and has moved completely into the &quot;techno&quot; genre.   <br />  There is one shining star on the album though...  &quot;Love Profusion&quot; has a great melody line which could easily be in the middle of the &quot;Ray of Light&quot; album.<br />  That's my opinion for today.. but I'll probably feel totally different about it tomorrow.   That's why Madonna is so famous I think... she can turn you off instantly until you give her a little more time and then you're hooked again!

0671015206|5.0|This book is exactly what my parents have been telling me for years!  For years I have earned good money in my banking job, and spent freely, living sometimes above my means.  This book rang a bell and woke me up to reality.  <br />My life has literally changed after reading this book.  I was living the high life - spending lots of money on fine dining, fine wine, travels around the world in luxury hotels, lots of boys' toys...basically the life of someone very wealthy.  Anyone who looked at me would assume that I was loaded.  But it didn't faze me since I have a great job that paid well, and I could afford it.  The truth is that while I had a good amount of savings even after my conspicuous consumption, my savings would only support my lifestyle for a maximum of 2 years or so if I no longer had an income.  This book made me realize &quot;financial freedom&quot; was not about being able to spend lots of the money that you earned, but about saving for the future so you don't have to worry about whether you can continue to earn a lot of money.<br />I highly recommend this book to anyone who wants to maintain financial freedom and the ability to walk away from a job without worrying about where money was going to come from.

Turning an artificial life form is not a new idea in Hollywood, as films such as \\"Bicentennial Man\\" and \\"Pinocchio\\", which is what part of the story of this film is based on, have already been done. Haley Joel Osment, as in \\"The Sixth Sense\\", does another great job in his role as David, the android robot desperately seeking to become a real boy, with strong feelings for his mother played by Frances O'Connor. One negative thing about this film is the ending, which to me failed as a point to end the film. Had the film ended a little earlier, before the final scene, it would have been a much better ending. Robin Williams provides the voice for Dr. Know, the animated wizard, which aids David in his quest for becoming real. The animatronic teddy bear, appropriately named \\"Teddy\\" (how long did it take them to come up with that name) is also fun to watch. The closet scene in the beginning is a direct rip-off of E.T., as the animatronic teddy bear is a descendent from HAL from \\"2001: A Space Odyssey\\". Jude Law does a nice job as his role as \\"Gigolo Joe\\", as well as William Hurt, who plays the professor that designed the robots. All in all though, a neat idea for a film. Had Kubrick done it, it probably would have been better.

B000000W5N|5.0|When STICKY FINGERS was released in the spring of 1971, I had just seen GIMME SHELTER and went from being a semi-Stones fan to being a raving, proselytizing FANatic. I could not believe the sheer sonic ecstasy and lurid appeal of this album. STICKY not only coincides with the peak of the Stones, but rock n roll as well. From 1968 to 1972, the Stones created 5 classic masterpieces, something no other pop/rock artist/band has rivaled; not the Beatles, Dylan, Hendrix, the Who, not anyone. STICKY sits in between LET IT BLEED and EXILE, and is as good as either of them. It is nasty, poetic, bluesy, dark and dangerous. Everything a great rock n roll album should be. The musicianship is so sublime, it sounds like it flowed out of the players, rather than strummed, picked or pounded. Keith's mastery of incredible riffs is in full glory on this album, from BROWN SUGAR's crunchy raunch to DEAD FLOWERS' toe-tapping country licks. If you've never heard STICKY, or have never really HEARD it, give it a spin. It rocks, it moans, it cries and it rails as the greatest band in rock history proves you can't always get what you want, but you can rock the house down and still have a damn good time. This album is as good as rock n roll gets, I don't care how many flannel-wearing crybabies try to kick the Stones.
B000068PQ0|3.0|This is an enjoyable cd, nice background music, pleasant vocals, and fine production.  Some of the lyrics are pretty amusing.<br />But experimental, daring, or even very interesting? B000002AZ8|4.0|After releasing two amazing albums in 1991 and 1993, the cracks started to show when Pearl Jam released their third record, Vitalogy, in late '94.<br />Cracks in their sanity, cracks in lead singer Ed Vedder's psyche, and cracks in the overall band dynamic.<br />The album opens with three furious, acerbic songs making up in fury what they lack in melody. It's not until the fifth song, the haunting ballad \\"Nothingman,\\" that a true Pearl Jam classic appears. And while there are some solid songs the rest of the way -- the angry \\"Whipping,\\" anti-fame diatribe \\"Corduroy,\\" radio smash (though true-life tale of abuse) \\"Better Man,\\" anti-groupie rant \\"Satan's Bed,\\" and the haunting rumination on death and fame \\"Immortality\\" -- there are unfortunate duds as well. An instrumental goes nowhere, a spoken-word reflection on privacy is a joke, and the completely unlistenable 10-minute album closer \\"Stupid Mop (Hey Foxymophandlemama That's Me\\" keep this album from acheiving classic status.<br />That, and the seeming disappearance of lead guitarist Mike McCready. After peppering virtually every song on the first two records with his blistering, melodic leads, he's hard to find on Vitalogy, and when he does bust a lead, it goes nowhere, and in an awful, thin, weak tone. Maybe that was intentional, as Vedder wanted to try to establish \\"punk rock credibility\\" in the face of accusations from the likes of Kurt Cobqain of \\"selling out,\\" or perhaps McCready's rumored drug and alcohol problems kept him down. But these songs ache for leads that simply aren't there, even when they are there.<br />For all its faults, however, Vitalogy is still quite solid, if not a masterpiece. The best songs are true classics, and even the mistakes are worth listening to, both musically and lyrically, as a look into the vortex of a troubled band at a troubled time. We can only be thankful they made it through this dark period, though they would never sound this urgent (if confused) again.
B00005JL7Q|5.0|Hugh Grant is one of my favorite film performers.  Notice I don't say \\"actor.\\"  He doesn't really act, per se, since he's always riffing on basically the same character...usually with varying degrees of charming, slightly goofy befuddlement (NOTTING HILL, 9 MONTHS) or charm barely concealing nastiness (BRIDGET JONES).  In a film such as EXTREME MEASURES, where he played a doctor turned amateur sleuth, he just wasn't convincing.<br />So much of his success lies with his ability to pick roles tailor made for him, such as in 4 WEDDINGS AND A FUNERAL.  He's an intelligent leading man with impeccable comedic delivery.  When the material written for him is good, he is GREAT.  When it's mediocre, he's only OK to watch.  <br />ABOUT A BOY is the best script he's had to date (well, maybe 4 WEDDINGS is...hard to say).  He plays a rich, single lout who lives only to indulge himself and score with women.  He truly only thinks of his own pleasures...most of which are remarkably humdrum.  He's not a creep or pervert or hedonist, really, he's just monumentally self-indulgent.  He didn't even earn his fortune, he inherited it.<br />One day, he gets the bright idea of meeting women by joining a single-parent's support group.  He'll just pretend to be a single father, and all the single women who will greatly outnumber him will fall all over themselves over him.  AND HE'S RIGHT!!!  <br />But this is just where the movie gets started. Through a series of events involving trying to keep his secret just that, he ends up being stuck with a teenaged boy who is awkward and fatherless and extremely nerdy who also takes a liking for Grant and starts showing up at his apartment door every afternoon to watch TV.  Grant can't get rid of him...it's a kind of mild blackmail situation.  But slowly, slowly, slowly, the two begin to bond.  Grant, through sheer annoyance, begins to bully the kid into being less of a schlep.  And this tiny kernel of interest in another human being slowly begins to gnaw away at Grant's insular world.  He's upset by the changes he sees in himself, but he also becomes enchanted with the unique feeling of actually making an impression on others.<br />The movie is very funny and has lots of near farcical situations.  The laughs are never cheap, though, and most of the humor is character driven.  It's not an action packed film, but I laughed outloud at LOTS of it...Grant's delivery has never been better.  But it was also moving, but in a very non-Hollywood, tear-jerking way.  The viewer is nearly as startled as Grant's character to see that we've grown to really care about the main characters.<br />This is a terrific, moving comedy.  Every character is fully realized, even if only on screen for a scene or two.  It's beautifully filmed in London and there's not one moment where you feel you're watching an American movie.  It feels British through and through  (how weird for a film directed and produced by the brothers who brought us AMERICAN PIE...another movie that had surprising touches of drama that actually worked).  It's a sophisticated movie, sure to be hated by most kids...not that kids ever go to Hugh Grant movies anyway.  But for intelligent adults looking for a great two hours, with a story unlike any seen before, CHECK IT OUT!!  Highly, highly recommended.
